  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Tavarus Rogers, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
  Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-427
  Heard March 10, 2004 â€“ Filed July 7, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General 
          John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, 
          and Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, all of Columbia; and 
          Solicitor Randolph Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  A jury convicted Tavarus Rogers 
  of two counts of murder, five counts of kidnapping, one count of armed robbery, 
  and one count of first-degree burglary.Â  Rogers contends the trial judge erred 
  in admitting:Â  (1) the in-court identifications of two witnesses; and (2) a 
  note that Rogers allegedly wrote to a co-defendant while he was incarcerated 
  on the charges that are the subject of this appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS 
At approximately 12:30 a.m. on January 2, 1999, Jocelyn 
  Elizabeth Shough Wendel, James Mitchell Riley, and Kristal Mae Wire arrived 
  at a party held in the home of Paul Reischl on Coffin Point Road in Beaufort 
  County, South Carolina.Â  A number of people were present at the party including 
  Rogers, West McKinnon, Jonathon Gadsen, Collins Gadsen, John Byars, Paul Reischl, 
  and Toby Reischl.
Wendel and Wire testified they only knew a couple of 
  people at the party and were introduced to the others.Â  Both stated Rogers introduced 
  himself as â€œV.â€Â  After about an hour-and-a-half to two hours, Rogers, McKinnon, 
  and the Gadsens left the party.Â Â  
Approximately an hour-and-a-half later, two men knocked 
  on the door of Paul Reischlâ€™s home.Â  Byars opened the door and the men entered 
  the home wielding guns.Â  The men attempted to conceal their identity by using 
  some type of white cloth wrapped around their faces. 
Upon entering the home, the men started hitting Byars.Â  
  They then forced everyone to the floor and the first intruder began demanding 
  money and drugs from Paul Reischl.Â  Following these demands, he forced Reischl 
  to a back bedroom.Â  The second intruder, who apparently was witnessing the incident, 
  called out to the first intruder some variation of â€œdonâ€™t do it V,â€ shortly 
  after which the intruder shot Paul Reischl.Â  The shooter then returned to the 
  living room and confronted James Mitchell Riley.Â  After forcing Riley to hand 
  over his money, the intruder shot and killed him as well.Â  Before leaving the 
  house with the other man, the shooter told everyone in the house â€œyou didnâ€™t 
  see anything.â€Â  After the intruders left, Wire and Wendel ran to a nearby home 
  and called 911. 
Several hours after the shooting, Wire and Wendel gave 
  written statements to investigators.Â  In one of her two statements, Wire recounted 
  the incident and identified the intruders as â€œtwo black males.â€Â  She, however, 
  did not identify Rogers other than referencing the statement that was made during 
  the incident, â€œV donâ€™t do it.â€ Subsequently, investigators presented Wire with 
  three photographic lineups.Â  Wire was unable to identify anyone in these lineups.
Wendel also was unable to identify anyone in the three 
  photographic lineups that were presented to her shortly after the incident.Â  
  When describing the incident in her statement, Wendel noted that when the 
  two intruders entered the home, â€œI recognized him â€˜Vâ€™ as soon as he came in 
  the door.â€Â  Throughout her statement, she described the actions of â€œV.â€Â  She 
  also gave a physical description of â€œV.â€ 
On January 6, 1999, Rogers was detained on a coronerâ€™s 
  warrant. Two days later, while incarcerated, Rogers admitted to investigating 
  officers that he killed the two victims.Â  On January 10 and 21, 1999, Rogers 
  was arrested on warrants issued by a magistrate.Â Â Â Â Â  
On February 8, 1999, a Beaufort County grand jury indicted Rogers for two counts 
  of murder, six counts of kidnapping, one count of assault and battery with intent 
  to kill, one count of first-degree burglary, one count of armed robbery, and 
  one count of possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime. 

Prior to trial, Rogersâ€™s counsel sought to suppress 
  any in-court identifications of Rogers. Â Pursuant to Neal v. Biggers, 
  409 U.S. 188 (1972), [1]  the 
  judge held two in camera hearings regarding the in-court identifications 
  of Rogers by Wire and Wendel. Â Â 
During her testimony, Wire recounted the incident.Â  
  She testified that she recognized the intruders because she had seen them earlier 
  in the evening at the party.Â  Wire identified â€œVâ€ as present in the courtroom 
  by pointing to â€œthe one in the orange suit.â€ Â When questioned about her 
  ability to identify â€œV,â€ Wire stated she had seen the intruders earlier in the 
  evening at the party and she recognized their voices. Â She further testified 
  that the intrudersâ€™ faces were not completely covered with the white cloth when 
  they entered the home. Â Â 
On cross-examination, Wire admitted that she was unable 
  to identify anyone in the photographic lineups and she did not give a physical 
  description of the intruders, other than their race, in her written statement.Â  
  She also acknowledged that once she was ordered to the floor during the incident 
  she never looked up.Â  She further acknowledged that Rogers was the only African-American 
  male in the courtroom wearing an orange detention center uniform. Â She 
  also admitted that she had:Â  seen Rogers at a bond hearing; been informed by 
  an investigating officer that Rogers had been arrested; read newspaper articles 
  regarding the incident; and spoken with Wendell about the incident.
Detectives Sam Roser and Matthew Averill, investigating 
  officers, testified that they interviewed Wire after the incident and showed 
  her the photographic lineups.Â  Roser testified that Wire told him that she knew 
  the intruders were African-American because their masks were partially open.Â  
  She also told Roser that she identified â€œVâ€ by his braided hairstyle.
At the conclusion of the testimony, Rogersâ€™s counsel 
  argued Wireâ€™s in-court identification should be suppressed given:Â  Wire gave 
  no physical description of the intruders after the incident; she could not identify 
  Rogers in the photographic lineups; she had seen Rogers at a bond hearing; and 
  Rogers was the only African-American male in the courtroom wearing an orange 
  detention suit.Â  The judge denied the motion and ruled Wireâ€™s identification 
  was admissible.
In a subsequent hearing, the judge heard testimony regarding Wendelâ€™s identification 
  of Rogers.Â  Wendell testified that at the time of the incident she recognized 
  Rogers as one of the intruders because his mask fell down when he entered the 
  home.Â  She also knew him as the man who had introduced himself at the party.Â  
  Wendell admitted that she had not been able to identify Rogers in any of the 
  photographic lineups.Â  During her testimony, Wendell identified Rogers by pointing 
  to him and describing his attire as an orange jumpsuit.Â  On cross-examination, 
  she acknowledged that she had seen Rogers at a prior hearing and had read about 
  the incident in the newspaper. 
After the testimony concluded, Rogersâ€™s counsel moved to suppress Wendellâ€™s 
  identification.Â  He argued the in-court identification procedure was suggestive 
  in that it was the equivalent of an impermissible â€œshow-upâ€ procedure.Â  Additionally, 
  he contended Wendellâ€™s identification was not reliable on the grounds:Â  she 
  could not identify Rogers in a photographic lineup; she had seen Rogers at prior 
  court proceedings; she had reviewed newspaper articles regarding the incident; 
  and she had discussed the incident with the other victims as well as her father, 
  who had collected the newspaper articles.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The judge denied Rogersâ€™s motion to exclude Wendellâ€™s in-court identification.Â  
  Aside from addressing the reliability of Wendellâ€™s identification, the judge 
  also found Rogers could not claim undue prejudice from the identification of 
  him in court given the fact that his counsel chose not to use an alternate procedure, 
  i.e., placing other African-American males with similar characteristics 
  to Rogers at the defense table or in the courtroom. 
At trial, both Wendell and Wire testified regarding 
  the incident and identified Rogers as the man who shot the two victims.Â  They 
  also identified Rogers in the courtroom. 
Toby Reischl testified Rogers was at the party and was introduced as â€œV.â€Â  
  Although he could not positively identify the intruders, he testified that one 
  of the intruders was referred to as â€œV.â€Â  In addition to this testimony and 
  the testimony of the investigating officers, the State introduced, over the 
  objection of defense counsel, a note allegedly written by Rogers to his co-defendant 
  McKinnon while the two were incarcerated. 
The jury convicted Rogers of two counts of murder, five counts of kidnapping, 
  one count of armed robbery, and one count of first-degree burglary.Â  The judge 
  sentenced Rogers to life imprisonment for each count of murder and the first-degree 
  burglary charge, consecutive thirty-year terms for three of the kidnapping charges, 
  [2]  and a concurrent term of twenty-five years for armed robbery.Â  Rogers 
  appeals.
DISCUSSION
I.Â  
Rogers argues the trial judge erred in admitting the in-court identifications 
  of Wire and Wendel.Â Â Â Â  
â€œGenerally, the decision to admit an eyewitness identification is at the trial 
  judgeâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of such, 
  or the commission of prejudicial legal error.â€Â  State v. Moore, 343 S.C. 
  282, 288, 540 S.E.2d 445, 448 (2000).Â  â€œHowever, an eyewitness identification 
  which is unreliable because of suggestive line-up procedures is constitutionally 
  inadmissible as a matter of law.â€Â  Id.
â€œA criminal defendant may be deprived of due process of law 
  by an identification procedure that is unnecessarily suggestive and conducive 
  to irreparable mistaken identification.â€Â  State v. Brown, 356 S.C. 496, 
  502, 589 S.E.2d 781, 784 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œAn in-court identification of an 
  accused is inadmissible if a suggestive out-of-court identification procedure 
  created a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.â€ Id.Â  
  Suggestiveness alone, however, does not require the exclusion of evidence.Â  
  State v. Stewart, 275 S.C. 447, 450, 272 S.E.2d 628, 629 (1980).Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  â€œTo determine the admissibility of an identification, 
  the court must determine (1) whether the identification process was unduly suggestive 
  and (2) if so, whether the out-of-court identification was nevertheless so reliable 
  that no substantial likelihood of misidentification existed.â€Â  State v. Cheeseboro, 
  346 S.C. 526, 540, 532 S.E.2d 300, 308 (2001), cert. denied, 535 U.S. 
  933 (2002).Â  Furthermore, as reliability is the most important factor in determining 
  the admissibility of identification testimony, the key inquiry is whether under 
  all the circumstances the identification was reliable even though the confrontation 
  procedure may have been suggestive.Â  State v. McCord, 349 S.C. 477, 481, 
  562 S.E.2d 689, 691 (Ct. App. 2002); State v. Blassingame, 338 S.C. 240, 
  251, 525 S.E.2d 535, 541 (Ct. App. 1999).
Several factors should be considered in evaluating the totality of the circumstances 
  to determine the likelihood of a misidentification:

  (1) the witnessâ€™s opportunity to view the perpetrator at the time of the 
    crime, (2) the witnessâ€™s degree of attention, (3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s 
    prior description of the perpetrator, (4) the level of certainty demonstrated 
    by the witness at the confrontation, and (5) the length of time between the 
    crime and the confrontation.

McCord, 349 S.C. at 481, 562 S.E.2d at 691.Â  â€œOnly 
  after a determination as to the reliability of a witnessâ€™ identification has 
  been made by the trial court may the witness testify before the jury.â€Â  Moore, 
  343 S.C. at 289, 540 S.E.2d at 449.
Although there are questions and apparent inconsistencies involved in Wireâ€™s 
  and Wendelâ€™s in-court identifications, we do not believe the trial judge abused 
  his discretion in admitting their testimony.Â  Specifically, the judge applied 
  the correct standard in determining the admissibility of the testimony and there 
  is evidence to support his decision.Â  See State v. Wilson, 345 
  S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001) (An abuse of discretion occurs when 
  the conclusions of the circuit court either lack evidentiary support or are 
  controlled by an error of law.).
Initially, we find the fact that neither Wire nor Wendel could identify Rogers 
  in a photographic lineup is not dispositive of whether their identifications 
  were admissible.Â  See McCord, 349 S.C. at 483, 562 S.E.2d at 692 
  (â€œThe fact that a witness is unable to make a positive identification from a 
  photo array does not negate the reliability of their positive in-court identification.â€ 
  (quoting State v. Blanchard, 920 S.W.2d 147, 149 (Mo. Ct. App. 1996))); 
  State v. Scipio, 283 S.C. 124, 126-27, 322 S.E.2d 15, 17 (1984) (finding 
  in-court identification of defendant by victim was admissible even though victim 
  failed to identify defendant in photographic lineup).Â  
Similarly, the fact that the witnesses viewed Rogers at a bond hearing did 
  not preclude a finding that their in-court identification was reliable.Â  See 
  State v. Cunningham, 275 S.C. 189, 193, 268 S.E.2d 289, 291 (1980) (holding 
  victimâ€™s in-court identification was admissible even though victim saw the defendant 
  at a preliminary hearing prior to the in-court identification); State v. 
  Covington, 226 S.E.2d 629, 638 (N.C. 1976) (â€œ[T]he viewing of a defendant 
  in the courtroom during the various stages of a criminal proceeding by witnesses 
  who are offered to testify as to identification of the defendant is not, of 
  itself, such a confrontation as will taint an in-court identification unless 
  other circumstances are shown which are so â€˜unnecessarily suggestive and conducive 
  to irreparable mistaken misidentificationâ€™ as would deprive defendant of his 
  due process rights.â€ (quoting State v. Haskins, 178 S.E.2d 610, 612 (N.C. 
  1971))).
Turning to the requisite identification factors, we find there is evidence 
  to support the judgeâ€™s conclusion.Â  Both witnesses observed Rogers in a social 
  setting for several hours before the incident.Â  Wire testified that she was 
  able to identify Rogers because she had seen him earlier and his face was not 
  completely covered when he entered the home.Â  Wendel also testified that she 
  was able to immediately recognize Rogers when he returned to the home because 
  she saw his face.Â  Additionally, in her written statement, Wendel gave a detailed 
  description of the incident.Â  She also provided physical descriptions of â€œVâ€ 
  as well as the other intruder.Â  Furthermore, given the witnesses were held at 
  gunpoint their degree of attention would most likely have been acute.Â  Although 
  a significant amount of time elapsed, approximately three years, between the 
  incident and the hearing concerning the in-court identification testimony, both 
  witnesses were certain in their in-court identifications of Rogers.Â  Â Â 
Admittedly, Wire did not provide a description 
  of the intruders in her written statements beyond describing them as â€œtwo black 
  males.â€Â  However, any uncertainty as to the identification testimony went to 
  the weight of the evidence and not its admissibility.Â  See State v. 
  Distance, 594 S.E.2d 221, 226 (N.C. Ct. App. 2004) (â€œ[A]ny uncertainty in 
  an in-court identification goes to the weight and not the admissibility of the 
  testimony.â€).Â  This evidence was then for the jury to weigh.Â  See State 
  v. Stewart, 275 S.C. 447, 451, 272 S.E.2d 628, 630 (1980) (recognizing that 
  jury is to weigh identification testimony that has some questionable feature).
Finally, even if the in-court identifications were erroneously admitted, particularly 
  that of Wire, any error would not require reversal.Â  See State v. 
  Simmons, 308 S.C. 80, 83, 417 S.E.2d 92, 94 (1992) (stating â€œunder certain 
  circumstances, if the identification is corroborated by either circumstantial 
  or direct evidence, then the harmless error rule might be applicableâ€); State 
  v. Thompson, 276 S.C. 616, 620-21, 281 S.E.2d 216, 219 (1981) (recognizing 
  admission of improper in-court identification may be harmless error where the 
  evidence is merely cumulative to independent and overwhelming evidence of guilt), 
  habeas corpus granted by Thompson v. Leeke, 590 F. Supp. 110 (D.S.C. 
  1984) (finding improper in-court identification did not constitute harmless 
  error where:Â  robbery victim was the only eyewitness; victim could not identify 
  perpetrator on two occasions; investigating officer pointed out defendant as 
  the man who robbed the victim; victim, at trial, was â€œalmost positiveâ€ that 
  defendant was the perpetrator; and the only other testimony identifying defendant 
  was that of his accomplice and his accompliceâ€™s wife), affâ€™d, 756 F.2d 
  314 (4th Cir. 1985).Â Â  
Because the in-court identification testimony was 
  not the only evidence identifying Rogers, any error would be harmless.Â  Here, 
  Wire, Wendel, and Toby Reischl all testified that they believed Rogers was the 
  intruder who shot the victim because Rogers introduced himself to them at the 
  party as â€œV,â€ and each person heard the second intruder say â€œDonâ€™t do it V.â€Â  
  Wire also testified she recognized the intruders from earlier in the evening 
  by their voices.Â  See Stewart, 275 S.C. at 451, 272 S.E.2d at 
  630 (finding witnessesâ€™ voice identification of defendant was admissible as 
  to the issue of the reliability of the in-court identification).Â  Rogers does 
  not challenge this evidence on appeal.Â  Additionally, Wendel was able to identify 
  Rogersâ€™s co-defendant by the clothing he had worn during the party.Â  Based on 
  the foregoing, we affirm the judgeâ€™s decision to admit the identification testimony.

II.
Rogers asserts the trial judge erred in refusing to suppress the note allegedly 
  written by him to his co-defendant while incarcerated.Â  In support of this assertion, 
  he contends the note was obtained pursuant to an illegal arrest.Â  Alternatively, 
  he argues that even if the note was not fruit of the illegal arrest, it should 
  have been excluded as being more prejudicial than probative. 
Prior to trial, Rogersâ€™s counsel moved to exclude any 
  inculpatory statements made by Rogers while illegally detained under the coronerâ€™s 
  warrant. Â Because the coronerâ€™s warrant was invalid and the State did 
  not have probable cause to arrest Rogers at the time he confessed to shooting 
  the victims, counsel moved to suppress the admission as â€œfruit of the poisonous 
  tree.â€Â  See Taylor v. Alabama, 457 U.S. 687, 690 (1982) (â€œ[A] 
  confession obtained through custodial interrogation after an illegal arrest 
  should be excluded unless intervening events break the causal connection between 
  the illegal arrest and the confession so that the confession is â€˜sufficiently 
  an act of free will to purge the primary taint.â€™â€ (quoting Wong Sun v. United 
  States, 371 U.S. 471 (1963))).
After a hearing, the trial judge granted Rogersâ€™s motion.Â  He found that at 
  the time the statement was made the State lacked probable cause to arrest Rogers.Â  
  He further held the coronerâ€™s warrant was invalid, as conceded by the State, 
  given it was issued without legal authority.Â  Because the State â€œfailed to prove 
  that the taint of the Fourth Amendment violation was purged,â€ the judge suppressed 
  all of the alleged statements as the â€œfruit of the poisonous tree.â€ 
Based on this earlier ruling, Rogersâ€™s counsel objected 
  at trial to the admission of the note allegedly written by Rogers to co-defendant 
  West McKinnon.Â  Counsel argued the note was not relevant and even if found to 
  be relevant, admitting it into evidence would be unfairly prejudicial.Â  He asserted 
  there was no indication who wrote the letter or who was the intended recipient. 
  Additionally, counsel contended the note should be excluded as evidence obtained 
  from Rogersâ€™s illegal detention under the coronerâ€™s warrant.Â  He asserted that 
  the magistrateâ€™s warrant, which was issued after the coronerâ€™s warrant, did 
  not cure the Fourth Amendment violation because this warrant would not have 
  been obtained but for the information illegally obtained under the coronerâ€™s 
  warrant.Â  The trial judge denied the motion, finding the note was admissible 
  given it was volunteered and Rogers was not being questioned at the time it 
  was found.Â  
Officer Richard Rivers of the Beaufort County Detention 
  Center was then permitted to testify that on January 22, 1999, he saw Rogers 
  slip a magazine into an adjoining cell.Â  The magazine was retrieved and the 
  handwritten note was found stuck between the pages.Â  A South Carolina Law Enforcement 
  Division fingerprint analyst found eleven prints on the note, eight of which 
  matched those of Rogers.Â  PhilÂ  Foote, another Beaufort County Corrections Officer, 
  testified that West McKinnon was in the cell in which Rogers placed the magazine.Â Â  

The solicitor read the note as follows:

  â€œWhat did you tell Mrs. Wilson (the Public Defenderâ€™s investigator)?Â  She 
    said our stories are f---ed up.Â  I told her that after we left P sh-- you 
    drop themâ€ â€“ up in brackets again â€“ â€œ(Cee and Bro) off at C sh-- and drop 
    me off in Saxonville at luck sh-- about 1 a.m. or later.Â  Then I called you 
    that morning and you took me to Ladyâ€™s Island with CAP about 7 or 8 a.m.Â  
    You gotta f---ing holla at me less you done told these crackas you was there 
    at the time of the sh--, what?Â  We gotta have our stories â€œtop of the lineâ€, 
    unquote.Â  (Flush this sh-- â€“ rip it up first*) (*Write me back*).â€

â€œThe fruit of the poisonous tree doctrine holds that 
  where evidence would not have come to light but for the illegal actions of the 
  police, and the evidence has been obtained by the exploitation of that illegality, 
  the evidence must be excluded.â€Â  State v. Plath, 277 S.C. 126, 134, 284 
  S.E.2d 221, 226 (1981) (citing Wong Sun v. United States, 371 U.S. 471 
  (1963)), overruled on other grounds by State v. Short, 333 S.C. 
  473, 511 S.E.2d 358 (1999), and State v. Collins, 329 S.C. 23, 495 S.E.2d 
  202 (1998).Â  â€œEven if the arrest was illegal, the fruit of the poisonous tree 
  doctrine will not apply to a confession if it is freely and voluntarily given.â€Â  
  Id. at 134-35, 284 S.E.2d at 226.Â  
Even assuming Rogers was illegally detained when the note was seized and that 
  its contents constituted a confession, we find the note was not the fruit of 
  the illegal arrest.Â  Our decision is based on our supreme courtâ€™s holding in 
  State v. Funchess, 255 S.C. 385, 179 S.E.2d 25 (1971), cert. denied, 
  404 U.S. 915 (1971).Â  In Funchess, the court directly confronted this 
  issue, stating:

  We conclude and hold that every statement or confession made by a person 
    in custody as the result of an illegal arrest, is not involuntary and inadmissible, 
    but the facts and circumstances surrounding such arrest and the in-custody 
    statement should be considered in determining whether the statement is voluntary 
    and admissible. Voluntariness remains as the test of admissibility.

Id. at 391, 179 S.E.2d at 28. Â  
In the instant case, there is no evidence that the note was the product of 
  questioning by law enforcement.Â  Instead, it is clear the note was produced 
  and passed along voluntarily.Â  Moreover, at the time the note was written Rogers 
  had been served with the magistrateâ€™s warrant and apparently had spoken with 
  a public defender.Â  Thus, there were intervening acts that broke any causal 
  connection between the note and the illegal arrest.Â  Accordingly, we find the 
  trial judge was correct in concluding the note was not the fruit of the illegal 
  arrest.
Furthermore, we disagree with Rogersâ€™s contention that the note was not relevant 
  and was unfairly prejudicial.Â  While Rogers argues the note is too vague to 
  be admitted into evidence, we believe the note constitutes circumstantial evidence 
  of Rogersâ€™s guilt and was not so prejudicial as to outweigh it probative value.Â  
  See Rule 401, SCRE (â€œâ€˜Relevant evidenceâ€™ means evidence having any tendency 
  to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination 
  of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€); 
  Rule 403, SCRE (â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative 
  value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.â€).Â  Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION 
Based on the foregoing, we affirm the admission of the in-court identifications 
  of Rogers as well as the admission of the note written while Rogers was incarcerated.
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ. and CURETON, AJ., concur.


 
   
    [1]  Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972) (wherein the United States 
    Supreme Court developed a two-prong inquiry to determine the admissibility 
    of an out-of-court identification).Â  

 
   
    [2] Â  Although the jury convicted Rogers of five counts of kidnapping, 
    which included the two counts involving the murder victims, the judge apparently 
    declined to sentence Rogers for the remaining kidnapping charges given he 
    was also convicted of the murders.Â  See State v. Perry, 278 
    S.C. 490, 495, 299 S.E.2d 324, 327 (1983), cert. denied, 461 U.S. 908 
    (1983) (holding, pursuant to section 16-3-910, life imprisonment sentence 
    for kidnapping murder victim was precluded where defendant was sentenced to 
    life imprisonment for murder).

  In The Court of Appeals
 
   
     
       
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
       
        Charles Gilbert, Jr., 
          Appellant. 
      
    
  


Appeal 
  From Lexington County
  Â Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished 
  Opinion No.Â  2004-UP-428
  Heard June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  July 9, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
       
        Acting Deputy Chief Attorney 
          Wanda P. Hagler, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan 
          McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant 
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant 
          Attorney General W. Rutledge Martin, all of Columbia; and Solicitor 
          Donald V. Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
        
    
  

PER 
  CURIAM:Â  Charles Gilbert, Jr. appeals his conviction for trafficking cocaine, 
  arguing the trial court erred in: (1) admitting evidence discovered during the 
  search of his vehicle because the arresting officer did not have probable cause 
  to make the traffic stop; (2) admitting evidence discovered during the search 
  of his vehicle because the traffic stop was the result of impermissible racial 
  profiling; (3) finding the Stateâ€™s strike of a black, female juror was proper; 
  (4) refusing to admit into evidence a copy of section 56-5-4450 of the South 
  Carolina Code and refusing to charge the jury on that statute; and (5) refusing 
  to charge the jury with the law concerning the requirement that police have 
  probable cause or reasonable suspicion to stop a vehicle.Â  We affirm pursuant 
  to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the authorities that follow.
Probable 
  Cause for Traffic Stop: Whren v. United States, 517 U.S. 806, 810 
  (1996) (explaining that the decision to stop an automobile is reasonable when 
  police have probable cause to believe a traffic violation has occurred); S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 56-5-4840 (Supp. 2003) (prohibiting the use of any device that alters 
  the original design or performance of headlights).
Racial 
  Profiling: Whren, 517 U.S. at 813 (holding that when there are adequate 
  grounds to perform a traffic stop, the officerâ€™s subjective motivations for 
  making the stop do not cause evidence obtained during the stop to become inadmissible); 
  State v. 192 Coin-Operated Video Game Machs., 338 S.C. 176, 200, 525 
  S.E.2d 872, 885 (2000) (requiring defendants attempting to establish a case 
  for selective prosecution to show: (1) they were singled out for prosecution 
  when others similarly situated were not, and (2) the governmentâ€™s discriminatory 
  selection was based upon an impermissible ground, such as the defendantsâ€™ race, 
  religion, or the exercise of their first amendment right to free speech).
Peremptory 
  Strikes: Purkett v. Elem, 514 U.S. 765 (1995) (requiring the proponent 
  of a peremptory strike to offer a race-neutral explanation for using the strike 
  once the other party challenges the strike); State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 
  114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996) (explaining that the opponent of a peremptory strike 
  carries the ultimate burden of persuading the trial court that the other party 
  exercised strikes in a discriminatory manner).
Admitting 
  Statutes into Evidence and Refusing To Charge the Jury on Statutes and Probable 
  Cause: Rule 104(a), SCRE (providing judges, not juries, determine questions 
  concerning the admissibility of evidence).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, 
  C.J., STILWELL, J. and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â

  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        D. Ann Jennings, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        William B. Jennings, 
          Respondent. 
      
    
  


Appeal 
  From Lexington County
  Â Richard W. Chewning, III, 
  Family Court Judge

Unpublished 
  Opinion No. 2004-UP-429
  Submitted April 6, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  July 9, 2004

AFFIRMED 
  AS MODIFIED

 
   
     
      
        J. Michael Taylor, of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        W. Michael Duncan, of Columbia, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER 
  CURIAM:Â  The family court granted Ann Jennings (Wife) a divorce from William 
  Jennings (Husband) on the ground of adultery.Â  Wife appeals the alimony award, 
  equitable division of marital property, and imputation of income to Wife.Â  We 
  affirm as modified. [1] 
FACTS
Husband 
  and Wife married in June 1982 and separated nearly eighteen years later in May 
  2000. [2] Â  Wife filed for temporary 
  relief, and she was granted use of the home (though Husband made mortgage payments) 
  and temporary alimony of $500 per month.Â  After discovery was conducted, it 
  was revealed that Husband had committed adultery.Â  Wife filed an amended complaint, 
  seeking a divorce on the grounds of adultery or one yearâ€™s continuous separation.Â  
  
In the 
  final order, the family court granted Wife a divorce on the ground of Husbandâ€™s 
  adultery.Â  The court also imputed income to Wife and awarded her $400 per month 
  in temporary alimony for eight years.Â  The court then equitably apportioned 
  the marital property between the parties.Â  Wife received:Â  one-third of the 
  General Electric stock held in Husbandâ€™s name; one-half of Husbandâ€™s Janus account; 
  one-half of Husbandâ€™s retirement account; a 1991 Buick; and a payment of $2,200 
  from Husband for her half interest in the partiesâ€™ timeshare.Â  Husband received:Â  
  one-half of the Janus and retirement accounts; various items of personal property; 
  the timeshare; and a 1998 Ford.Â  The court found the partiesâ€™ home was titled 
  in Wifeâ€™s name, ordered Wife to assume the mortgage payments, and awarded Husband 
  special equity in the amount of $65,250 from Wife.Â Â  
After 
  Wife filed a motion for reconsideration pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, the family 
  court maintained the amount of Wifeâ€™s alimony but changed it to permanent periodic 
  alimony.Â  The court did not change any other portions of the prior order.Â  Wife 
  appeals.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, 
  this Court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of 
  the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 
  199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).Â  This broad scope of review does not, 
  however, require this Court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  
  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).Â  
  Neither is the Court required to ignore the fact that the family court judge, 
  who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their 
  credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. 
  Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 525, 280 S.E.2d 541, 541 (1981).
   

  
LAW/ANALYSIS
  
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Alimony 
   

    Wife argues the 
      family court erred in imputing income to her when determining the alimony 
      award.Â  She further argues the court erred in awarding her only $400 in 
      monthly alimony.Â  
    A.Â Â Â Â Â  
      Imputation of Income
    
Wife argues the family 
  court erred in imputing income to her because she is unable to work as a result 
  of being afflicted with Raynaudâ€™s Disease.Â  
    
â€œAlimony is a substitute 
  for the support that is normally incident to the marital relationship.â€Â  McElveen 
  v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 599, 506 S.E.2d 1, 9 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The purpose 
  of alimony is to place the supported spouse in the position he or she enjoyed 
  during the marriage. Â Id.Â  However, alimony should not â€œserve as a disincentive 
  for spouses to improve their employment potential or to dissuade them from providing, 
  to the extent possible, for their own support.â€Â  Id.Â  In making an award 
  of alimony, the family court must consider several factors, including each partyâ€™s 
  earning potential and reasonably anticipated income.Â  S.C. Code 
  Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C)(4), (6) (Supp. 2003) (â€œIn making an award of alimony or separate 
  maintenance and support, the court must consider and give weight in such proportion 
  as it finds appropriate to all of the following factors: . . . (4) the employment 
  history and earning potential of each spouse; . . . (6) the current and reasonably 
  anticipated earnings of both spouses. . . .â€).
    In McElveen, 
      the wife testified that she was not sure she could work full-time due to 
      her fibromyalgia, and she did not feel she could return to work until her 
      children were grown and the house was organized.Â  This court noted there 
      was no medical evidence in the record establishing the wifeâ€™s condition 
      precluded her employment and that, in fact, the wife pointed to non-medical 
      reasons to delay her return to work.Â  McElveen, 332 S.C. at 600, 
      506 S.E.2d at 9-10.Â  
    In the present 
      case, Wife had several part-time jobs during the marriage, including her 
      job driving for the Commission for the Blind at the time of the hearing.Â  
      Wife testified that she suffered from Raynaudâ€™s Disease, 
      [3]  which caused severe migraines lasting up to three days, upon exposure 
      to cold temperatures or stress.Â  Thus, Wife explained that the only reason 
      she was able to work her part-time job driving for the Commission for the 
      Blind is because she was not depended upon and could call in sick at any 
      time. 
    
In the final order, the family court 
  considered Wifeâ€™s health, but noted that no medical evidence was presented regarding 
  any ailment that prevented her from working.Â  The court specifically found that 
  Wife was â€œphysically and mentally capable of working full time.â€ Â The court 
  essentially found that Wife was underemployed and imputed a monthly income of 
  $885.Â  The sum of $885 per month resulted from Wife earning minimum wage while 
  working forty hours per week. Â 
    
    As in McElveen, 
      Wifeâ€™s testimony in the present case that she could not work due to her 
      illness was not supported by any medical evidence.Â  Sections 20-3-130(C)(4) 
      and (C)(6) require the family court to consider each partyâ€™s earning potential 
      and reasonably anticipated income.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) 
      (Supp. 2003).Â  Because there was no evidence to support a finding that Wife 
      could not work due to her illness and Wife was working a part-time job at 
      the time of the final hearing, we find the family court did not commit an 
      abuse of discretion in considering Wifeâ€™s earning potential and in imputing 
      income to her.Â Â Â  
    
B.Â Â Â Â Â  
  Amount of Alimony
    
Wife argues her $400 
  periodic alimony award was inadequate because the family court did not achieve 
  the desired objective of placing her close to the economic position she enjoyed 
  during the coupleâ€™s marriage.Â  We agree that the court failed to provide adequate 
  alimony to Wife.Â  
    
An award of alimony 
  rests within the sound discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed 
  absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 184, 554 
  S.E.2d 421, 424 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Factors to be considered in making an alimony 
  award include:Â  (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health 
  of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history 
  and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living during the marriage; 
  (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current 
  and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and non-marital 
  properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct 
  or fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; and (13) other 
  factors the court considers relevant.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2003).Â  
  
    
At the time of the trial, Wife was 
  sixty-one years old and did not have a high school diploma.Â  Wife brought a 
  pre-marital estate of $250,000 into the marriage. Â Wife stated the couple enjoyed 
  a â€œcomfortable lifestyleâ€ that included annual out-of-state vacations and a 
  timeshare in Myrtle Beach. Â Â Shortly after the parties married, Wife purchased 
  and operated a dry-cleaning business until she sold it in 1986.Â  As previously 
  discussed, Wife testified that she suffered from Raynaudâ€™s Disease, but she 
  held several part-time jobs during the marriage.Â  However, at the request of 
  Husband, Wife never obtained a permanent, full-time job after selling her dry-cleaning 
  business in 1986. 
    Wife received 
      $258.33 in gross monthly income from her part-time job, and she expected 
      to begin receiving Social Security income in the amount of $483 per month 
      upon reaching the age of sixty-two.Â  Wife listed $2,808 in expenses on her 
      financial declaration, which included the $943 mortgage payment made by 
      Husband.Â  
    
At the time of the 
  final hearing, Husband was fifty-seven years old, had two years of a college 
  education, and the family court found he had a gross monthly income of $5,176, 
  and a net monthly income of $3,710. [4] Â  He had $3,173.83 in monthly expenses, including 
  paying $500 in alimony pursuant to the temporary order and paying the mortgage 
  on Wifeâ€™s house.Â  Although Husband denied he had an affair during the marriage, 
  he admitted he had a close secret friendship with one woman during the marriage 
  and a sexual relationship with another woman after the parties separated. 
    In awarding $400 
      in monthly alimony, the family court noted that it considered all the relevant 
      factors set forth in section 20-3-130(C).Â  The order specifically noted 
      the partiesâ€™ ages, Husbandâ€™s income, Wifeâ€™s ability to work, and Wifeâ€™s 
      expectation of Social Security benefits.Â  Although not discussed in the 
      paragraph dealing with alimony, the court mentioned other facts that are 
      statutory considerations in section 20-3-130(C): the duration of the marriage, 
      Husbandâ€™s marital misconduct, and marital and non-marital properties. 
    
Reviewing the order 
  shows that the family court considered many of the factors relevant to an alimony 
  award.Â  However, we do not believe the court provided an adequate award of alimony 
  to Wife.Â  
    
The order provided 
  that Wife would be responsible for the $943 mortgage payment on her home, leaving 
  her with expenses of $2,808.Â  Including the imputed minimum wage income of $885 
  and the Social Security income of $483, Wifeâ€™s total income would be $1,368. [5] Â  This would leave her with a monthly deficit of $1,440.Â  Including 
  the $400 in alimony awarded by the family court, Wife will still have a deficit 
  of $1,040.Â  
    
Husband, on the other 
  hand, listed a gross monthly income of $5,176, and a net monthly income of $3,710.35.Â  
  Reducing his $3,173.83 in expenses by the $943 mortgage payment assumed by Wife 
  and the $500 temporary alimony payment, Husband had expenses of $1,730.83.Â  
  Thus, after paying his expenses and before calculating any alimony award, Husband 
  would have $1,979.52 in surplus funds.Â  
    
Considering the significant 
  drop in Wifeâ€™s standard of living, Wifeâ€™s expenses, Husbandâ€™s income, and Husbandâ€™s 
  infidelity, we find the family court erred in only awarding $400 in alimony 
  to Wife.Â  We modify the award and order Husband to pay Wife $900 in alimony 
  beginning with the month of August 2004.Â  See Morris v. Morris, 
  335 S.C. 525, 533, 517 S.E.2d 720, 724 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding that even though 
  the family court applied the factors relevant to an alimony award, the award 
  was inadequate in light of the husbandâ€™s significant income, the drop in the 
  wifeâ€™s standard of living, and the husbandâ€™s adultery).Â  
    II.Â Â Â Â Â  
      Apportionment of Property
    Wife argues the 
      family court erred in apportioning the property.Â  She argues the method 
      used by the court to determine Husbandâ€™s interest in the home was erroneous 
      and the $62,250 award of special equity to Husband was excessive. [6] Â  She further argues the court 
      erred in dividing up various other items of personal property, including 
      the timeshare and the porch furniture. 
    
The apportionment of marital property 
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Bungener 
  v. Bungener, 291 S.C. 247, 251, 353 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Section 
  20-7-472 lists fifteen factors for the court to consider in equitably apportioning 
  a marital estate.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2003); Greene v. Greene, 
  351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œAlthough nonmarital 
  property is not subject to equitable distribution as such, . . . the family 
  court may properly award the other spouse a special equity in the property.â€Â  
  Greene, 352 S.C. at 337, 569 S.E.2d at 398.Â  A spouse has an equitable 
  interest in improvements to property to which he or she has contributed, even 
  if the property is nonmarital.Â  Johnson v. Johnson, 296 S.C. 289, 299, 
  372 S.E.2d 107, 113 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  On appeal, this court looks to the overall 
  fairness of the apportionment.Â  Id. at 300, 372 S.E.2d at 113.Â  If the 
  end result is equitable, it is irrelevant that the appellate court would have 
  arrived at a different apportionment.Â  Id.Â  
    
Wife complains the family court erred 
  in calculating the amount of Husbandâ€™s special equity.Â  Wife provided $99,525.28 
  of her personal, non-marital funds towards the construction of the partiesâ€™ 
  home such that only an $85,000 mortgage was needed.Â  The house was titled in 
  Wifeâ€™s name, and the mortgage was jointly titled in both partiesâ€™ names.Â  At 
  the time of the final hearing, the balance due on the mortgage was $40,949.44.Â  
  The parties do not dispute that Husband made all of the mortgage payments on 
  the house, amounting to $130,500. 
    
Wife introduced an appraisal valuing 
  the home at $240,000.Â  Husbandâ€™s appraisal indicated the home was valued at 
  $270,000.Â  The family court adopted Husbandâ€™s valuation, and, after subtracting 
  the amount remaining on the mortgage, the family court determined the house 
  had a net equity of $229,000.Â  To determine the amount of equity due to Husband, 
  the court considered two methods of calculation.Â  First, Wifeâ€™s separate, non-marital 
  contribution to the acquisition of the home was subtracted from the net equity, 
  which resulted in $129,000 of equity to be divided between the parties.Â  Second, 
  the court considered the $130,500 Husband made in total mortgage payments as 
  equity to be divided equally between the parties.Â  The court adopted the second 
  method of valuation and determined Husband was due $65,250 in special equity 
  from Wife.Â Â  
    
Wife argues this method of calculating 
  Husbandâ€™s special equity interest in the home was erroneous because the marital 
  portion of the net equity in the home was only 30.68 [7]  percent.Â  Thus, she asserts only 
  $70,272.71 [8]  of the equity 
  was marital and Husband was only entitled to $35,136.35. 
    
Although the family court used an 
  unusual method to calculate Husbandâ€™s special equity, we find no error with 
  the fairness of the apportionment.Â  There is no set formula to assist the court 
  in dividing property.Â  See, e.g., Smith v. Smith, 294 S.C. 194, 
  198, 363 S.E.2d 404, 407 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œIn valuing marital assets, the trial 
  court â€˜is fully within its discretion to choose the valuations of one party 
  over those of the other party.â€™â€).Â  Further, Husband paid all of the mortgage 
  payments on Wifeâ€™s home.Â  Husbandâ€™s special equity award only amounted to 28.5 
  percent of the net equity of the home.Â  Because we find the special equity award 
  to be fair, the family court did not abuse its discretion in determining Husbandâ€™s 
  special equity in Wifeâ€™s home.Â  
    
Further, we find no error with the 
  courtâ€™s determination that Husband was entitled to the timeshare and various 
  personal property items, including the porch furniture.Â  With the exception 
  of the General Electric stock, of which Wife received one-third, the court awarded 
  one-half of the marital assets to each party. Â Husband was awarded the timeshare 
  and ordered to pay Wife for her one-half interest in it.Â  An appraisal service 
  listed over 200 items of personal property in Wifeâ€™s home with a total value 
  of $14,457.Â  Husband indicated he wanted approximately fifty of those items, 
  valued at $3,607, which included the porch furniture.Â  The court awarded Husband 
  the items he requested.Â  Considering these facts, we find no abuse of discretion.Â  
  
    
CONCLUSION
    The family court did not abuse 
      its discretion in imputing income to Wife or awarding special equity to 
      Husband.Â  However, the court erred in calculating the amount of the alimony 
      award.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is 
    AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED. 
      
    
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ. and CURETON, 
  AJ., concur.
   
  
   
     [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
      to Rule 215, SCACR.
  
   
     
      [2]  No children were born as a result of this marriage. 
  
   
     
      [3]  Raynaudâ€™s Disease is defined as â€œa peripheral vascular disorder 
      found most frequently in females between the ages of 18 and 30.Â  It is characterized 
      by abnormal vasoconstriction of the extremities upon exposure to cold or 
      emotional stress.â€Â  Taberâ€™s Cyclopedic Medical Dictionary 1563-64 
      (16th ed. 1989).
  
   
     
      [4]  Husband submitted a new financial declaration at the final hearing 
      that is not included in the record.Â  He testified regarding his income and 
      expenses and the family court adopted his amounts.Â Â Â  
  
   
     
      [5]  This assumption does not take into account the effect, if any, 
      that a full-time income would have on Wifeâ€™s ability to continue receiving 
      Social Security income.
  
   
     
      [6]  The family court found the home was titled solely in Wifeâ€™s name 
      and awarded Husband special equity in the home.Â  Although the court did 
      not specifically find that the home was Wifeâ€™s nonmarital property, it was 
      treated as such and the parties do not dispute that it was nonmarital.Â  
      Husband, however, argues on appeal that the house was transmuted into marital 
      property.Â  The issue of transmutation was not raised to or ruled upon by 
      the family court judge and, thus, is not preserved for review.Â  McDavid 
      v. McDavid, 333 S.C. 490, 497, 511 S.E.2d 365, 368-69 (1999) (holding 
      an issue not raised to or ruled on by the family court should not be considered 
      by the appellate court).Â  Accordingly, we proceed as if the home is non-marital 
      property.Â  
  
   
     
      [7]  Wife arrives at this percentage using a cost approach.Â  She adds 
      her contributions to the house to the amount the mortgage had been paid 
      to obtain the â€œtotal costâ€ of the house: $99,525.28 + $44,050.56 = $143,575.84. 
      Â She then finds that the amount the mortgage had been paid, or $44,050.56, 
      was 30.68 percent of the total cost, and this equaled the percentage to 
      be used to calculate the amount of marital equity.Â  
  
   
     
      [8]  Wife arrives at the equity in the home by subtracting the amount 
      the mortgage had been paid from the value of the home:Â  $270,000 - $40,949.44= 
      $229,050.56.

PER CURIAM:Â  The circuit court terminated 
  Dwayne Elliott Johnsonâ€™s probation three years earlier than its scheduled expiration.Â  
  The South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services appeals, 
  arguing the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to entertain Johnsonâ€™s 
  petition.Â  However, the department failed to include Johnsonâ€™s original petition 
  or the courtâ€™s final order in the record on appeal, failed to place the documents 
  contained in the record in the proper order, and failed to provide a proper 
  index.
We affirm 
  [1]  pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  South 
  Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, Op. No. 3824 (S.C. Ct. App. filed 
  June 14, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 25 at 91) (noting the burden of presenting 
  a sufficient record on appeal rests on the appellant and the omission of the 
  courtâ€™s order alone could justify a finding that the issues on appeal are unpreserved 
  for appellate review); Harkins v. Greenville County, 340 S.C. 606, 616, 
  533 S.E.2d 886, 891 (2000) (affirming the circuit court on an issue because 
  appellant had not met its burden of presenting an adequate record on appeal); 
  York v. Conway Ford, Inc., 325 S.C. 170, 173, 480 S.E.2d 726, 728 (1997) 
  (â€œThe record should include the ruling on appeal.â€); South Carolina State 
  Highway Depâ€™t v. Meredith, 241 S.C. 306, 311, 128 S.E.2d 179, 181 (1962) 
  (â€œThe transcript of record is the source of our information as to what occurred 
  in the trial of the case below; its very object is to inform the Court authoritatively 
  of the legal questions contested below and of the facts pertaining thereto.â€); 
  Rule 210(h), SCACR (â€œ[T]he appellate court will not consider any fact which 
  does not appear in the record on appeal.â€).
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, 
  A.J., concur.

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
David H. March and Christine A. March,       
Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Presidential Brokerage, Inc., Scott Key, P. Georgia French, and Mark 
        French,        Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-431
Submitted June 9, 2004 â€“ Filed July 15, 2004 


REVERSED


  
    
      
Stephen Lynwood Brown, of Charleston, for Appellants.
David and Christine March, of St. Helena, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Presidential Brokerage, Inc., 
  Scott Key, P. Georgia French, and Mark French (collectively â€œPresidentialâ€) 
  appeal from an order denying their motion to compel arbitration.Â  We reverse. [1] 
FACTS
This case arises out of a dispute concerning 
  brokerage services Presidential agreed to perform for investors David and Christine 
  March.Â  In September 1998, the Marches opened four brokerage accounts with Presidential.Â  
  For each account, the Marches were required to sign various documents that set 
  forth the terms governing their relationship with the company.Â  
One of these documents, the â€œMedallion Account 
  Agreement,â€ contained the following notice in bold, capital letters: â€œI acknowledge 
  that the agreementâ€™s terms and conditions contain a predispute arbitration clause 
  on page 24 and acknowledge receipt of a copy of those terms and conditions.â€ 
  The arbitration clause referred to was contained in a separate booklet entitled 
  â€œMedallion Account Terms & Conditions.â€Â  The clause provided that â€œall controversies 
  which may arise between [the Marches and Presidential] concerning any transaction 
  or the construction, performance, or breach of this or any other agreement between 
  us . . . shall be determined by arbitration.â€ The Marches do not dispute that 
  they signed all of the documents presented to them by Presidential representatives, 
  including the Medallion Account Agreement. 
By 1999, Presidential had lost a significant portion 
  of the money in the Marchesâ€™ investment accounts.Â  Shortly thereafter, the Marches 
  closed their Presidential accounts.Â  A subsequent review of Presidentialâ€™s brokerage 
  actions convinced the Marches that Presidential had mismanaged their money.Â  
  In October 2001, they initiated the present action against Presidential alleging 
  causes of action for fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, negligence, and violations 
  of the South Carolina Securities Act. 
Presidential denied the allegations and filed a 
  motion to dismiss and compel arbitration pursuant to the arbitration clause 
  contained in the Medallion Account Agreement signed by the Marches.Â  Shortly 
  thereafter, the Marches amended their original complaint to allege Presidential 
  fraudulently induced them to sign all of the documents pertaining to the brokerage 
  agreement, including the document containing the arbitration clause. Â Specifically, 
  the Marches added a fifth cause of action for â€œFraud and Constructive Fraud 
  in Plaintiffâ€™s Signatures on Arbitration Provisions and Investment Incentive 
  Provisions.â€Â  Under this claim, they alleged, in pertinent part:

46.Â  After the funds were transferred 
  [to Presidential], on several occasions the Defendant Scott Key [a representative 
  of Presidential and named defendant in this action] came by the Plaintiffâ€™s 
  house with various papers that were to be signed.Â  He would generally uncover 
  only the part of the paper for a signature and told the Plaintiffs that they 
  needed to be signed for access to their accounts.Â  The Plaintiffs were never 
  given copies of the papers, were never given the option to read the papers and 
  any explanations given about the content of the papers were falsely answered.
47.Â  The Plaintiffs were forwarded 
  copies of the papers after this suit was filed and found that numerous items 
  on the papers had been put in that were not there when the Plaintiffs signed 
  them.Â  The dates on the papers were changed or made up and numerous of these 
  papers were signed by Georgia French, who the Plaintiffs have never met.
48. The representations and actions 
  by the Defendants to the Plaintiffs to induce them to sign these papers was 
  to obtain their consent to arbitration and their argument[ [2] ] to allow speculative investments by the Defendants. 


In the circuit court, the Marches argued 
  the determination of whether the arbitration clause was valid could not itself 
  be subject to arbitration but was rather a question for the court to decide.Â  
  The circuit court agreed, allowing discovery to proceed on the sole issue of 
  the enforceability of the arbitration clause.Â  All of the other claims raised 
  by the Marches as to Presidentialâ€™s performance under the terms of the brokerage 
  agreement were held in abeyance pending the courtâ€™s determination on arbitration. 

LAW/ANALYSIS
Presidential argues the circuit court erred in 
  denying its motion to compel arbitration.Â  We agree.
In Prima Paint Corporation v. Flood & Conklin 
  Manufacturing Co., 388 U.S. 395, 406 (1967), the United States Supreme Court 
  held that general allegations of fraud in the inducement of a contract are insufficient 
  to prevent the invocation of the arbitration provision of the contract.Â  Our 
  state supreme court has explained how the rule of Prima Paint should 
  be applied by our courts:

We join the jurisdictions which 
  have rejected limiting the holding in Prima Paint. We hold a party cannot 
  avoid arbitration through rescission of the entire contract when there is 
  no independent challenge to the arbitration clause. Fraud as a defense to 
  an arbitration clause must be fraud specifically as to the arbitration clause 
  and not the contract generally.

South Carolina Pub. Serv. Auth. v. Great W. Coal (Ky.), 
  312 S.C. 559, 562-63, 437 S.E.2d 22, 24 (1993) (emphasis added).
In this case, although the Marches amended their 
  complaint to separately plead a cause of action for fraudulent inducement of 
  the arbitration agreement, the allegations set forth in both the complaint and 
  the Marchesâ€™ affidavits only support their claim that they were fraudulently 
  induced to sign the entire contract, not specifically the arbitration clause. 
  [3] Â  Under the rule of Prima Paint and Great Western Coal, 
  therefore, it was improper for the circuit court to rule that the validity of 
  the arbitration clause was for the courtâ€™s determination.Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court 
  is
 REVERSED.
 HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J. and CURETON, 
  A.J., concur.

 
   [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [2]  This is probably a typographical error that was 
    most likely intended to be â€œagreementâ€ rather than â€œargument.â€

 
   
     
    [3]    In their joint affidavit, the Marches asserted: â€œWe were totally 
    and completely deceived with the entire matter of opening this account and 
    what was going to occur in connection with it.â€Â

THIS OPINION 
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT 
  IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Robert H. Charron, d/b/a Liberty Ministries,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Horton Homes, Inc.,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Oconee County
Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court 
  Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-432
Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ July 15, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Kurt M. Rozelsky and Jennifer S. Barr, both of Greenville, for Appellant. 
W. Grady Jordan, and Robert T. Usry, both of Easley, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Robert H. Charron sued Horton Homes, Inc. to recover damages 
  for defects in a mobile home.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Charron 
  on his breach of warranty claims.Â  Horton appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of 
  his motions for directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict or 
  for a new trial.Â  We affirm. [1] 
FACTS
Charron purchased a mobile home manufactured by Horton from Discount Housing 
  Center.Â  Hortonâ€™s one-year limited warranty on the home stated â€œeach part of 
  the manufactured home shall be free under normal use and service from defects 
  in material and workmanship for a period of one (1) year after the initial delivery[.]â€Â  
  The warranty required Charron to promptly report any defects to Discount Housing 
  or Hortonâ€™s service department to receive repairs.Â  Under the terms of the contract, 
  Discount Housing was responsible for handling and coordinating repairs.Â  
Charron immediately experienced problems with the mobile home.Â  The 
  large sections of the home were misaligned by almost an inch and a half.Â  Water 
  leaked into the structure, shingles fell off, within a few months the foundation 
  skirting collapsed, and the walls were bowed.Â  Charron notified Discount Housing 
  and Horton of the structural problems.Â  Both companies repeatedly sent repairmen 
  to fix the defects, but the attempts at repair were unsatisfactory and serious 
  structural problems remained uncorrected. 
Charron brought this action for breach of warranties, negligence, 
  and violation of the South Carolina Unfair Trade Practices Act. [2] Â  At trial, the jury awarded Charron 
  $27,500 on his breach of warranty claim.Â  The trial court denied Hortonâ€™s post-trial 
  motions.Â  
SCOPE
OF REVIEW 
Upon appellate review 
  of an action at law tried by a jury, the juryâ€™s findings of fact will not be 
  disturbed unless the reviewing tribunal determines that no evidence in the record 
  supports the juryâ€™s conclusion.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 
  266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  â€œFurthermore, in deciding motions 
  for directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict, the evidence 
  and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to 
  the non-moving party.Â  If more than one inference can be drawn from the evidence, 
  the case must be submitted to the jury.â€Â  Bishop Logging Co. v. John Deere 
  Indus. Equip.Â  Co., 317 S.C. 520, 526, 455 S.E.2d 183, 186-87 (Ct. App. 
  1995).Â  
  DISCUSSION
  I.Â  Breach of 
    Warranties Claim
  Horton contends the trial court 
    erred in submitting Charronâ€™s claim for breach of warranties to the jury, 
    arguing Charron failed to comply with the notice requirement of the express 
    warranty, all implied warranties were conspicuously disclaimed and, in any 
    event, Charron failed to prove breach of any implied warranties.Â  We disagree.
  Horton claims Charron 
    failed to comply with the notice requirement of the sales contractâ€™s express 
    warranty, arguing he did not give Horton prompt notice of defects and an opportunity 
    to cure.Â  Whether Charron gave Horton reasonable notice and an opportunity 
    to cure is a question of fact properly reserved for the jury.Â  Draffin 
    v. Chrysler Motors Corp., 252 S.C. 348, 353, 166 S.E.2d 305, 308 (1969).Â  
  
  Under the express 
    warranty provision, â€œ[i]n order to obtain performance of any obligations under 
    the foregoing warranty the purchaser shall . . . [p]romptly report any defects 
    in materials or workmanship to [Discount Housing], or to the service department 
    of Horton Homes, Inc.â€Â  Charron testified he informed Discount Housing â€œfrom 
    day oneâ€ sections of the mobile home were misaligned. Â After Discountâ€™s 
    repairmen failed to cure the structural defects, Charron contacted Horton 
    repeatedly by telephone and in writing requesting further repairs.Â  In one 
    of his letters, Charron included a list of the numerous defects with the home. 
    Â Horton acknowledged it sent several repairmen out to the mobile home 
    in response to Charronâ€™s requests. Â Contrary to Hortonâ€™s assertions, 
    the record reveals Charron was in regular communication with Discount Housing 
    and Horton requesting repair service for numerous defects in the home.Â  
  Horton further claims 
    it was denied the opportunity to cure the alleged defects, citing a single 
    instance when Charron refused a service call from a Horton repairman.Â  The 
    refusal occurred after months of repeated and unsuccessful service calls.Â  
    Charron explained he declined the repairmanâ€™s request to attempt repairs for 
    two reasons.Â  First, the repairman called on a Sunday evening and wanted to 
    come then or the following day, which was Labor Day, neither of which was 
    acceptable to Charron.Â  Secondly, Charron had been assured by Horton that 
    factory employees would perform any required repair work, and the repairman 
    who called on this occasion advised Charron that he was an independent contractor.Â  
    A month later, Charron again allowed Horton to send a repairman to his property. 
    Â Repairmen from Discount Housing and Horton made multiple trips to 
    Charronâ€™s home both before and after the refusal.Â  
  The record contains 
    evidence of Charronâ€™s request for repairs and Hortonâ€™s admission it dispatched 
    repairmen to the home to repair defects.Â  This evidence is sufficient to create 
    a jury question as to whether the express warrantyâ€™s notice requirement was 
    met and, if so, whether there were adequate opportunities to cure any defects.Â  
    Accordingly, we find the trial court properly submitted these questions of 
    fact on the issue of breach of express warranty to the jury. [3] Â  
  II.Â  Competent Evidence of Damages
  Horton contends the 
    circuit court erred in finding Charron presented competent evidence of damages 
    for his breach of warranty claims.Â  We disagree.Â  
  The trial court denied Hortonâ€™s 
    motions for a directed verdict based on the assertion Charron failed to prove 
    damages on his breach of warranty claims. Â A trial courtâ€™s grant or 
    denial of a directed verdict can only be reversed when there is no evidence 
    to support the ruling below.Â  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife & Marine 
    Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 28-29, 491 S.E.2d 571, 573 (1997).Â  
  A.Â  Measure of Damages
  Charron presented 
    no evidence of the fair market value of the mobile home at the time he accepted 
    it for delivery.Â  Therefore, Horton asserts he failed to present sufficient 
    proof of damages as required by the Uniform Commercial Code.Â  The applicable 
    section of the U.C.C. measures a buyerâ€™s damages for breach as â€œthe difference 
    at the time and place of acceptance between the value of the goods accepted 
    and the value they would have had if they had been as warranted . . . .â€Â  
    South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-714(2) (2003).Â  
  Although Charron did not present 
    evidence of the homeâ€™s value at the time of delivery, the $44,280 purchase 
    price is prima facie evidence of its warranted value, and his expert witness 
    testified partial repair costs for defects would be approximately $60,000.Â  
    Long v. Quality Mobile Home Brokers, Inc., 271 S.C. 482, 484, 248 S.E.2d 
    311, 312-313 (1978) (stating a goodâ€™s purchase price is prima facie evidence 
    of its warranted value).Â  A competent estimate of the cost of repairs is sufficient 
    to create a factual question for the jury regarding damages.Â  Scott v. 
    Fort Roofing & Sheet Metal Works, Inc., 299 S.C. 449, 451, 385 S.E.2d 
    826, 827 (1989).Â  The record contains written estimates of the repair costs 
    supported by expert testimony.Â  Accordingly, there is ample evidence of damages 
    to sustain the trial judgeâ€™s denial of a directed verdict in favor of Horton.
  B.Â  Qualification of Expert 
    Witness
  Finally, Horton asserts Charronâ€™s 
    expert witness was not qualified to testify about repair methods or costs 
    for mobile homes.Â  We disagree.
  Charronâ€™s expert witness was 
    a civil engineer licensed in three states and actively engaged in structural 
    engineering projects.Â  He personally designed support systems for buildings, 
    including mobile home roof trusses, and had previous work experience in a 
    mobile home manufacturing plant.Â  He also had considerable experience making 
    cost estimations for construction projects.Â  His specialized work experience 
    in structural engineering and cost estimation clearly made him more qualified 
    than the jury to give his opinion on the cost and extent of repairs required.Â  
  
  The qualification of an expert 
    witness and the admissibility of his testimony rest within the sound discretion 
    of the trial court.Â  Mizell v. Glover, 351 S.C. 392, 406, 570 S.E.2d 
    176, 183 (2002).Â  We will not disturb the courtâ€™s decision to exclude or admit 
    expert testimony absent a clear abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  â€œFor a court 
    to find a witness competent to testify as an expert, the witness must be better 
    qualified than the jury to form an opinion on the particular subject of the 
    testimony.â€Â  Id. (citing Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 
    326 S.C. 248, 252-253, 487 S.E.2d 596, 598 (1997)).Â  Accordingly, we find 
    the trial court did not err in qualifying Charronâ€™s witness as an expert, 
    and his testimony was properly admitted.
   AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, 
    J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â 

 
   
    [1]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 
    215, SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  Charron agreed not to pursue his cause of action under the 
    UTPA in exchange for Hortonâ€™s decision to abandon its motion challenging the 
    courtâ€™s jurisdiction.Â  

 
   
    [3]  Â Â Â Â Â Â  In light of our determination that Charronâ€™s claim for breach 
    of an express warranty was properly before the jury, the juryâ€™s general verdict 
    stands.Â  Because the juryâ€™s award could be predicated on Hortonâ€™s breach of 
    the express warranty alone, we need not address Hortonâ€™s questions regarding 
    disclaimer or breach of implied warranties.Â
