THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL 
  VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT 
  AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH 
  CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Quay Drakeford, Appellant, 
        
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        New South, Inc., Respondent. 
        
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw 
  County
  Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit 
  Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion 
  No. 2004-UP-433
  Submitted May 12, 2004 â€“ Filed 
  July 23, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Gerald F. Smith, of Columbia, 
          for Appellant.
        William Lee Duda, of Columbia, 
          for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER 
  CURIAM:Â  Quay Drakeford brought this action for breach of employment contract 
  against his former employer, New South, Inc., asserting that an employee handbook 
  created an employment contract and New South breached this employment contract 
  and the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  The trial court granted 
  New Southâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  We affirm. 
  [1] 
FACTS
Drakeford 
  was hired by New South, a lumber company, in 1995.Â  He worked there continuously 
  until he was terminated in 2000.Â  Shortly before his termination, Drakeford 
  was promoted to crew leader, supervising a six-person crew.Â  After Drakeford 
  became crew leader, a member of his crew asked to be reassigned.Â  When questioned 
  about her request, she began to cry and explained that Drakeford was a â€œbullyâ€ 
  and intimidated her.Â  She stated he used a â€œhatefulâ€ tone of voice and attitude 
  toward her.Â  Further investigation revealed several co-workers who said that 
  Drakeford referred to the distressed crew-member as â€œwhiteyâ€ when she was not 
  around and made other racially charged comments.Â  Additionally, it was alleged 
  he made verbal threats to another member of the crew.Â  
The 
  investigation also resulted in co-workers disclosing an incident in which Drakeford 
  allegedly used an open knife to point at another worker and made verbal threats 
  to that worker.Â  The co-worker who had been threatened with the knife also stated 
  that on another occasion, Drakeford came up behind him holding a piece of lumber 
  drawn back like a bat and when discovered said, â€œI could have got him if I wanted.â€Â  
  
Based 
  on its investigation of these allegations, New South terminated Drakeford for 
  creating a hostile work environment.Â  Drakeford sued New South for breach of 
  an employment contract and the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  
  Drakeford asserted that an employee handbook altered his at-will status, creating 
  an employment contract and that New South breached the employment contract when 
  it did not conform to an employee handbook policy creating a progressive disciplinary 
  policy. [2] Â  The trial court granted New Southâ€™s motion 
  for summary judgment, finding the employment handbook did not alter Drakefordâ€™s 
  at-will employment status, and without an employment contract there could be 
  no implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  The court subsequently 
  denied Drakefordâ€™s motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe 
  purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do 
  not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 
  58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when there 
  is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled 
  to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 
  S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).Â  The evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom 
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  
  â€œIt is well established that summary judgment should be granted â€˜. . . in cases 
  in which plain, palpable and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds 
  cannot differ.â€™â€Â  Anders v. S.C. Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 307 S.C. 
  371, 373, 415 S.E.2d 406, 407 (Ct. App. 1992) (quoting Main v. Corley, 
  281 S.C. 525, 526, 316 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1984)); see Bloom v. Ravoira, 
  339 S.C. 417, 425, 529 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2000) (finding where a verdict is not 
  reasonably possible under the facts presented, summary judgment is proper).Â  
  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Timeliness of appeal
New South 
  argues that this court lacks jurisdiction to consider the appeal because Drakeford 
  failed to timely serve the notice of appeal. [3] Â  We disagree.Â  
On August 
  22, 2002, Drakeford received written notice of the trial courtâ€™s order granting 
  New Southâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  He timely served his motion to alter 
  or amend the judgment on September 3, 2002. 
  [4] Â  The trial court denied the motion in an order filed October 1, 2002.Â  
  Drakeford served the notice of appeal on October 25, 2002.Â  
Rule 203(b)(1), 
  SCACR, provides, 

  A notice of appeal shall be served 
    on all respondents within thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice 
    of entry of the order or judgment.Â  When a timely motion for judgment n.o.v. 
    (Rule 50, SCRCP), motion to alter or amend the judgment (Rules 52 and 59, 
    SCRCP), or a motion for a new trial (Rule 59, SCRCP) has been made, the time 
    for appeal for all parties shall be stayed and shall run from receipt of written 
    notice of entry of the order granting or denying such motion.Â  

New South asserts that the timely 
  filing of a motion to alter or amend merely tolls the running of the thirty 
  day period for serving the notice of appeal rather than the thirty day period 
  beginning anew after the appellant receives the order granting or denying the 
  motion.Â  Thus, it contends the eleven days between Drakefordâ€™s receipt of the 
  original order and his service of the motion to alter or amend must be counted 
  against his time for serving the notice of appeal.Â Â  
We disagree with this interpretation 
  of the rule.Â  Rule 203(b)(1), SCACR, clearly states the time for serving the 
  notice of appeal â€œshall run from receipt of written notice of entry of the order 
  granting or denying [the timely post-trial motion].â€Â  The supreme court reiterated, 
  â€œUnder Rule 59(f), when such a motion is made, the time for appeal from the 
  judgment begins to run from the time of the order granting or denying the motion.â€Â  
  Otten v. Otten, 287 S.C. 166, 167, 337 S.E.2d 207, 208 (1985).Â  Thus, 
  Drakeford had thirty days from the date he received written notice of entry 
  of the order denying his motion to alter or amend to serve his notice of appeal.Â  
  As he served the notice of appeal within thirty days of the trial courtâ€™s issuance 
  of the order, we find he timely served his notice of appeal.Â  Thus, this court 
  has jurisdiction to consider his appeal.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  
II.Â  
  Breach of Contract
Drakeford 
  argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because material issues 
  of fact existed concerning whether New Southâ€™s employee handbook created an 
  employment contract.Â  We disagree.
South 
  Carolina recognizes the doctrine of employment at will in wrongful termination 
  actions.Â  Prescott v. Farmers Tel. Coop., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 334, 516 
  S.E.2d 923, 925 (1999).Â  Although some exceptions have been recognized, the 
  doctrine of employment at-will remains in South Carolina as a longstanding economic 
  incentive that provides the marketplace its necessary flexibility.Â  Prescott, 
  335 S.C. at 335, 442 S.E.2d at 925.Â  At-will employment may be terminated by 
  either party at any time, for any reason or for no reason at all.Â  Prescott 
  335 S.C. at 334, 516 S.E.2d at 925.Â  The general rule is that termination of 
  an at-will employee normally does not give rise to a cause of action for breach 
  of contract.Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 463, 560 
  S.E.2d 606, 610 (2002).Â  
However, 
  an employer and employee may choose to contractually alter the general rule 
  of employment at-will.Â  Prescott, 335 S.C. at 335, 442 S.E.2d at 925.Â  
  An employee handbook may create such a contract.Â  Small v. Springs, 292 
  S.C. 481, 485, 357 S.E.2d 452, 455 (1987).Â  The court in Small explained, 
  â€œIt is patently unjust to allow an employer to couch a handbook, bulletin, or 
  other similar material in mandatory terms and then allow him to ignore these 
  very policies as â€˜a gratuitous, nonbinding statement of general policyâ€™ whenever 
  it works to his disadvantage.â€ Id. at 485, 357 S.E.2d at 455.Â  
Although the Small court instructed 
  that an employer may continue at-will employment by inserting a conspicuous 
  disclaimer into the handbook, the supreme court subsequently ruled a disclaimer 
  is merely one factor to consider in ascertaining whether the handbook as a whole 
  conveys credible promises that should be enforced.Â  Id.; Fleming v. 
  Borden, 316 S.C. 452, 450 S.E.2d 589, 596 (1994).Â  The court in Fleming 
  explained, â€œ[A] handbook that contains both promissory language and a disclaimer 
  should be viewed as inherently ambiguous.Â  Thus, . . . the entire handbook, 
  including any disclaimer, should be considered in determining whether the handbook 
  gives rise to a promise, an expectation and a benefit.â€Â  Id. at 463-64, 
  450 S.E.2d at 596  (quoting Stephen F. Befort, Employee Handbooks and 
  the Legal Effect of Disclaimers, 13 Indus.Rel.L.J. 326, 375-76 (1991-92)).Â  
  
After 
  careful review of New Southâ€™s employee handbook, we find the provisions are 
  written in permissive language and accompanied by effective disclaimers of any 
  alteration of the at-will nature of employment. 
The 
  â€œIntroductory Statementâ€ in New Southâ€™s employee handbook specifically states 
  that employment is at-will, and this sentiment is repeated throughout the text, 
  including a section entitled â€œNature of Employment.â€Â  The general tenor of the 
  handbook is as a source of information.Â  Additionally, upon receipt of the handbook, 
  Drakeford signed a form that was part of the handbook in which he acknowledged 
  â€œthat this handbook is neither a contract of employment nor a legal document.â€Â  
  He admitted he had read the handbook after receiving it.Â  Drakeford also clearly 
  demonstrated his understanding of the basic principles underlying at-will employment, 
  as he explained his understanding of the handbook provisions as follows:Â  â€œThat 
  the person that is the employer has the right under any circumstance even one 
  that has been created, he can [terminate] you.Â  Even if you didnâ€™t do what was 
  stated that you did.â€Â  Typically, the question of whether a disclaimer is conspicuous 
  is a question of fact.Â  Williams v. Riedman, 339 S.C. 251, 264, 529 S.E.2d 
  28, 34 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  However, considering the written statements in 
  the policy, the acknowledgment, and Drakefordâ€™s professed knowledge, we find 
  the only reasonable inference from the evidence is that New South made an effective 
  disclaimer. 
However, 
  as stated above, the simple existence of a disclaimer is not determinative.Â  
  Instead, we must consider the actual language of the employment handbook to 
  determine if the handbookâ€™s provisions are couched in permissive or mandatory 
  language.Â  Examples of mandatory language from Conner include:Â  â€œ(1) 
  violations of the Code of Conduct â€˜will be disciplined,â€™ (2) â€˜discipline 
  shall be of an increasingly progressive nature,â€™ and (3) â€˜all employees 
  shall be treated fairly and consistently in all matters related to their 
  employment.â€™â€Â  Conner, 348 S.C. at 464 n.4, 560 S.E.2d at 611 n.4.Â  
We agree with the trial courtâ€™s determination 
  that the relevant sections of the New South employee handbook were couched in 
  permissive language.Â  The section on â€œProgressive Disciplineâ€ specified: 

  Although employment with New South 
    is based on mutual consent and both the employee and New South have the right 
    to terminate employment at will, with or without cause or advance notice, 
    New South may use progressive discipline at its discretion.Â  (emphasis 
    added).

The provision 
  further provided that â€œ[d]isciplinary action may call for any of three 
  steps,â€ and â€œ[t]here may be circumstances when one or more steps are 
  bypassed.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  When detailing the progressive policy, New South 
  stated that:Â  

  Progressive discipline means that, 
    with respect to most disciplinary problems, these steps will normally 
    be followed:Â  a first offense may call for a verbal written warning; 
    a next offense may be followed by a written warning; another offense 
    of the same nature within 6 months may result in termination, or receipt 
    of a third written reprimand for different offenses within a 12 month period 
    may then lead to termination of employment.

(emphasis 
  added).Â  In this provision, New South recognized â€œcertain types of employee 
  problems . . . are serious enough to justify either a suspension during investigation, 
  or, in extreme situations, termination of employment, without going through 
  the usual progressive discipline steps.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  
The â€œProgressive Disciplineâ€ provision 
  also referenced an â€œEmployee Conduct and Work Rulesâ€ policy, and stated that 
  it â€œincludes examples of problems that may result in immediate suspension 
  or termination of employment.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The â€œEmployee Conduct and 
  Work Rulesâ€ policy declares itself to be a non-exclusive list of conduct that 
  â€œmay result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination of 
  employment. . .â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  Included in the list of unacceptable behavior 
  is â€œ[f]ighting or threatening violence in the workplace,â€ â€œdisrespectful conduct,â€ 
  and â€œunlawful or unwelcome harassment.â€Â  This policy provision concludes by 
  stating â€œ[e]mployment with New South is at the mutual consent of New South and 
  the employee, and either party may terminate that relationship at any time, 
  with or without cause, and with or without advance notice.â€Â  
Drakeford relies on Jones v. General 
  Electric Co., 331 S.C. 351, 503 S.E.2d 173 (Ct. App. 1998) in his argument 
  for reversal of the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment.Â  The handbook in 
  Jones also included a list of possible offenses in its Work Rules section. 
  Class I violations were described as behaviors â€˜â€œin which a single offense subjects 
  the involved employee(s) to dischargeâ€â€™ while Class II offenses provided for 
  progressive discipline for repeated violations and were described as â€œâ€˜offenses 
  which, with repetition, will lead to disciplinary time off and/or discharge.â€â€™Â  
  Id. at 366-37, 503 S.E.2d at 181-82.Â  The Work Rules section of the handbook 
  in Jones, especially for Class II violations, used clearly mandatory 
  language with regard to punishment.Â  Furthermore, Jones testified that the G.E. 
  representatives instructed the new employees during orientation that the handbook 
  was G.E.â€™s â€œbible,â€ and that they abided by the procedures described therein.Â  
  Id.Â  at 368, 503 S.E.2d at 182.Â  This court concluded, â€œ[T]here is a 
  material question of fact as to whether G.E.â€™s employee handbook, particularly 
  the section entitled Work Rules, established mandatory procedures or whether 
  the handbook contains merely permissive provisions outlining employee conduct.â€Â  
  Id. at 370, 503 S.E.2d at 183.
In contrast 
  to the handbook in Jones, the New South handbook consistently used permissive 
  language when discussing behavioral offenses and punishment.Â  Accordingly, we 
  find the facts of the present case distinguishable from those in Jones.Â  
  
Drakeford 
  also argues that his termination violates the â€œProblem Resolution (Grievance)â€ 
  policy of the employee handbook because New South made a commitment to an open 
  and frank atmosphere in which problems or complaints would be heard.Â  The handbookÂ  
  provision upon which Drakeford relies stated a general commitment to fair treatment 
  and specifically promised that â€œ[n]o employee will be penalized, formally or 
  informally, for voicing a complaint with New South in a reasonable, business-like 
  manner, or for using the problem resolution procedure.â€Â  This provision does 
  not make any promise related to Drakeford, as he did not pursue the â€œProblem 
  Resolution (Grievance)â€ steps that are outlined in the policy.Â  
Drakeford 
  further argues the trial court erred in not considering the entire handbook 
  and only focusing on the relevant provisions.Â  However, the circuit court explained 
  in the preamble of its order that it had considered all evidence in the record, 
  and the entire contract was in the record.Â  
Furthermore, 
  our own review of the employment handbook demonstrates that New South had assumed 
  through mandatory language only finite and limited duties.Â  New South used mandatory 
  language to describe its duty to be an equal opportunity employer, make reasonable 
  accommodations under the Americans with Disabilities Act, comply with legal 
  obligations, provide specified employment benefits, give paid holiday time for 
  specified holidays, comply with workersâ€™ compensation law, give specified sick 
  day benefits, give jury duty benefits, provide short and long term disability 
  benefits, offer a 401(k) savings plan, pay the employees on specified paydays, 
  make certain pay deductions as required by law, pay overtime, investigate all 
  reports of workplace violence, and provide various forms of leave.Â  Many of 
  the duties accepted by New South in its employee handbook are required by law 
  or provide guidelines that are essential to the operation of a business.Â  To 
  use these duties to find that an employeeâ€™s status had been altered from at-will 
  would severely undermine the at-will doctrine so as to make an informational 
  employment handbook impossible. 
After reviewing the employment handbook 
  at question in its entirety, we conclude Drakefordâ€™s at-will status was not 
  altered.Â  See Darby v. Horton Elec. Co., Op. No. 25839 (S.C. Sup. 
  Ct. filed July 6, 2004) (Shearouse Adv.Sh. No. 28 at 14, 23) (stating employerâ€™s 
  manual exemplified the appropriate manner in which to give employees a guide 
  regarding their employment without altering the at-will employment relationship 
  where the manual contained conspicuous disclaimers, which the employee understood 
  and the disciplinary procedure contained permissive language and did not provide 
  for mandatory progressive discipline).Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court 
  did not err in granting summary judgment to New South on Drakefordâ€™s claim for 
  breach of employment contract and breach of the implied covenant of good faith 
  and fair dealing. [5] 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and KITTREDGE, 
  JJ., concur.Â 
   

 
   
    [1]  Â Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, 
    SCACR.

 
   
    [2]  The â€œProgressive Disciplineâ€ policy states â€œa first offense may call 
    for a verbal warning; a next offense may be followed by a written warning; 
    another offense of the same nature within 6 months may result in termination. 
    . . .â€Â  

 
   
    [3]  New South originally raised this argument in a motion to dismiss.Â  
    This court denied the motion on February 13, 2003.Â  New South renewed its 
    argument in its Respondentâ€™s brief.Â  

 
   [4]  Monday, September 2, 2002, was Labor Day.Â  

 
   
    [5]  The implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing is predicated 
    upon the existence of a contract.Â  Williams v. Riedman, 339 S.C. 251, 
    274, 529 S.E.2d 28, 40 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  As we have concluded the trial 
    court properly determined the employment handbook did not alter Drakefordâ€™s 
    at-will status and thus no contract existed, Drakefordâ€™s cause of action for 
    breach of an implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing must fail.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        Courtney Danielle Saxon, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Department of Transportation and Thomas Cooler, Defendants,
        of whom South Carolina Department of Transportation is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
  Â Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-435
  Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed July 23, 2004

AFFIRMED

 
   
     
      
        Darrell T. Johnson, Jr. and Mills Lane Morrison, Jr., both of Hardeeville, 
          for Appellant.
        I. McDuffie Stone, III, of Bluffton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This case arises from an automobile 
  collision.Â  As a result of the accident, Saxon filed suit against the South 
  Carolina Department of Transportation (DOT) for failure to maintain necessary 
  sight lines at a stop sign. [1] Â  
  The circuit court granted a directed verdict in favor of the DOT on the basis 
  of proximate cause and lack of notice.Â  We affirm. [2] 
FACTS
Saxon was driving along 
  Darby Plantation Road when she came to a stop sign and attempted a left turn 
  onto Route 39.Â  She stopped at the stop sign, drove her car forward to gain 
  a better view of Route 39, and then looked in both directions before turning.Â Â  
  When Saxon pulled out, Thomas Coolerâ€™s vehicle struck the rear driverâ€™s side 
  door of Saxonâ€™s vehicle.Â  Cooler was driving at or below the speed limit of 
  45 miles per hour, and he did nothing to contribute to the accident. 
Saxon filed suit against 
  the DOT for negligence, alleging it failed to maintain the vegetation along 
  Route 39 and thereby failed to maintain the proper sight line and sight distance 
  for cars entering from Darby Plantation Road.Â  At trial, Saxon stated that she 
  did not see another car before turning and that prior to turning she had inched 
  her car past the stop sign to see past overgrown trees and bushes.Â  Cooler testified 
  that he was able to see the stop sign on Darby Plantation Road, but he did not 
  see Saxonâ€™s car until the accident. 
Mr. Lohr, an engineer and 
  Saxonâ€™s expert witness, testified the DOT provided inadequate sight distance 
  along Route 39.Â  However, during cross-examination, he admitted the 468 feet 
  sight distance actually provided should have been sufficient for Saxon to detect 
  a vehicle traveling up to 47.7 miles per hour.Â  Because Coolerâ€™s car was traveling 
  less than 47.7 miles per hour, Lohr opined the intersectionâ€™s sight distance 
  was safe.Â  Dr. King, an expert witness for the DOT, also testified the intersection 
  had more than adequate sight distance.Â  Additionally, a highway patrolman, who 
  investigated the accident, testified he did not observe any visual obstructions 
  the day of the accident.Â  The trooper also stated:Â  he traveled the road frequently; 
  it was his duty to report any problems such as obstructions; and he never saw 
  any problems.Â Â  
After the close of testimony, 
  the trial court granted the DOTâ€™s motion for a directed verdict because there 
  was no evidence:Â  (1) the accident was proximately caused by any breach of duty 
  by the DOT; and (2) the DOT had notice of the dangerous condition.Â  Pursuant 
  to Rule 59, SCRCP, Saxon moved for judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV) 
  and for a new trial.Â  The court denied these motions. Â Saxon appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the 
  trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably 
  can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the 
  motion and to deny the motion where either the evidence yields more than one 
  inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  Creech v. South Carolina Wildlife 
  & Marine Res. Depâ€™t, 328 S.C. 24, 29, 491 S.E.2d 571, 573 (1997).Â  
  In deciding whether to grant or deny a directed verdict motion, the trial court 
  is concerned only with the existence or nonexistence of evidence.Â  Long v. 
  Norris & Assocs., 342 S.C. 561, 568, 538 S.E.2d 5, 9 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
  This court can only reverse the trial court when there is no evidence to support 
  the ruling below.Â  Creech, 328 S.C. at 29, 491 S.E.2d at 573. 
DISCUSSION
I.
Saxon argues the trial court erred in granting 
  a directed verdict on the issue of proximate cause.Â  She contends the evidence 
  is conflicting and supports the conclusion that the accident was proximately 
  caused by the DOTâ€™s negligence.Â  Because this issue required a credibility determination, 
  she asserts it should have been submitted to the jury. 
  [3] Â  We disagree. 
In a negligence action, a plaintiff must show:Â  
  (1) the defendant owes a duty of care to the plaintiff; (2) the defendant breached 
  the duty by a negligent act or omission; (3) the defendantâ€™s breach was the 
  actual and proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injury; and (4) the plaintiff 
  suffered an injury or damages.Â  Andrade v. Johnson, 356 S.C. 238, 
  245, 588 S.E.2d 588, 592 (2003).Â  â€œProximate cause requires proof of both 
  causation in fact and legal cause, which is proved by establishing foreseeability.â€Â  
  Bray v. Marathon Corp., 356 S.C. 111, 116-17, 588 S.E.2d 93, 95 (2003).Â  
  â€œCausation in fact is proved by establishing the plaintiffâ€™s injury would not 
  have occurred â€˜but forâ€™ the defendantâ€™s negligence. . . .Â  Legal cause turns 
  on the issue of foreseeability.Â  An injury is foreseeable if it is the natural 
  and probable consequence of a breach of duty.â€Â  Schmidt v. Courtney, 
  357 S.C. 310, 326, 592 S.E.2d 326, 335 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œForeseeability 
  is not determined from hindsight, but rather from the defendantâ€™s perspective 
  at the time of the alleged breach.â€ Parks v. Characters Night Club, 345 
  S.C. 484, 491, 548 S.E.2d 605, 609 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œFurthermore, legal cause 
  is ordinarily a question of fact for the jury.Â  Only when the evidence is susceptible 
  to only one inference does it become a matter of law for the court.â€Â  Oliver 
  v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Highways & Pub. Transp., 309 S.C. 313, 317, 
  422 S.E.2d 128, 131 (1992).Â  
In this case, the trial court granted a directed 
  verdict on the ground Saxon failed to present any evidence the accident was 
  proximately caused by a breach of duty by the DOT.Â  Specifically, the court 
  found:Â  (1) neither Saxon nor Cooler testified that inadequate sight distance 
  caused the accident; and (2) Saxonâ€™s expert, Lohr, testified that inadequate 
  sight distance was not the cause of the accident.
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Saxon, we find Saxon failed 
  to present any evidence that the DOTâ€™s failure to maintain the vegetation proximately 
  caused the accident.Â  Saxonâ€™s own expert witness testified the sight lines were 
  insufficient because of overgrown bushes and trees only if a car was driving 
  on Route 39 in excess of 47.7 miles per hour. Â Â Â However, it was stipulated 
  that the speed limit was 45 miles per hour and that Cooler was driving at or 
  below the speed limit.Â  Cooler also acknowledged that the bushes did not obstruct 
  his view.
Saxon argues, notwithstanding the testimony of 
  her own expert witness, the lay testimony was sufficient to submit the issue 
  of proximate cause to the jury.Â  Saxon refers to her direct testimony in which 
  she stated that she had to inch up before pulling out to turn left â€œ[b]ecause 
  the trees and bushes are overgrown and itâ€™s kinda hard to see all the way down 
  Malphrus Road to your left.â€ Â She also points out that she and Cooler both testified 
  that even though they were looking, they did not see the other vehicle until 
  after the accident.Â  In light of this testimony, Saxon urges this court to reverse 
  based on Poston v. Southeastern Constr. Co., 208 S.C. 35, 36 S.E.2d 858 
  (1946), and Roscoe v. Grubb, 237 S.C. 590, 118 S.E.2d 337 (1961).Â Â Â  

In Poston, a workerâ€™s compensation case, 
  the claimant testified that an accident at work caused his eyes to become inflamed 
  and, in turn, severely affected his vision.Â  Due to the accident, he was unable 
  to perform the same types of carpentry jobs he did before the accident.Â  The 
  treating physician testified the claimant came to him with red, inflamed, and 
  irritated eyes. In contrast to the claimantâ€™s testimony, he stated, as â€œa medical 
  fact,â€ the claimantâ€™s farsightedness could not have been caused by any event 
  but must have existed all of the claimantâ€™s life.Â  The claimant was awarded 
  benefits for the work-related injury.Â  In considering the employerâ€™s appeal, 
  our supreme court found that had the case been tried before a jury, the trial 
  judge would have submitted the issue to the jury because there was a conflict 
  between the claimantâ€™s testimony and the medical testimony.Â  Poston, 
  208 S.C. at 38, 36 S.E.2d at 860.Â  The court stated, â€œa medical opinion which 
  conflicts with the physical facts will not be permitted to control the determination 
  of a factual controversy.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).Â  The court affirmed 
  the award of benefits, finding sufficient lay testimony that the claimantâ€™s 
  reduced vision was caused by the accident.Â  The court pointed to the evidence 
  that prior to the accident, the claimant had been able to work as a carpenter 
  without the aid of glasses.Â  The court held that when expert testimony is disregarded, 
  the decision must be based on other competent evidence.Â  Id. at 39.
Similarly, in Roscoe, the court disregarded 
  the testimony of a physician that the decedent died as a result of an automobile 
  accident that occurred almost one year prior to the death.Â  Roscoe, 237 
  S.C. at 592-93, 118 S.E.2d at 338.Â  The court noted that â€œwhere physical injury 
  is coincident with or immediately follows an accident and is naturally and directly 
  connected with it lay testimony may be sufficient to carry to the triers of 
  the facts the issue of whether or not the accident proximately caused it, despite 
  expert medical testimony that it did not.â€Â  Id. at 596, 118 S.E.2d at 
  340.Â  Together, these cases properly situate the expert witnessâ€™s testimony 
  as non-binding and intended to aid the fact finder.Â  Hines v. Pac. Mills, 
  214 S.C. 125, 132, 51 S.E.2d 383, 385 (1949).
In the instant case, expert witnesses for both 
  Saxon and the DOT testified that given the speed of Coolerâ€™s vehicle there was 
  sufficient sight distance, and thus, the vegetation did not in fact cause the 
  accident.Â  In contrast to the pointedly different testimony in Poston, 
  neither Saxon nor Cooler testified the accident was caused by an inability to 
  properly see because of an overgrowth of vegetation.Â  Cooler testified he could 
  see the stop sign, but he never saw Saxonâ€™s vehicle.Â  Saxon testified that difficulty 
  in seeing down Route 39 caused her to inch past the stop sign prior to turning, 
  and she did not see any cars prior to turning onto Route 39.Â  She, however, 
  did not testify she was unable to see Coolerâ€™s vehicle because of the overgrowth.Â  
  Instead, she testified the overgrowth forced her to take another action, which 
  involved moving her car forward.Â  Saxon was also vague in her testimony regarding 
  how far down the road she could see.Â  Although she testified that she could 
  not see â€œall the way downâ€ the road, this testimony did not quantify the sufficiency 
  of her sight distance.Â  Even construing Saxonâ€™s testimony in the light most 
  favorable to her, as we are required to do, we find there is no testimony or 
  inferences to be drawn as to causation in fact.Â  Accordingly, the trial court 
  properly directed a verdict in favor of the DOT. 

II.
Saxon asserts the trial court erred in granting 
  the DOTâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the issue of notice.Â  She contends 
  the issue should have been submitted to the jury because the DOT conceded there 
  was evidence of a breach of duty, which necessarily encompasses notice, and 
  moreover, the DOT failed to affirmatively show a lack of notice. 
â€œThe South Carolina Tort Claims Act provides that 
  the State, its agencies, political subdivisions, and other governmental entities 
  are â€˜liable for their torts in the same manner and to the same extent as a private 
  individual under like circumstances,â€™ subject to certain limitations and exemptions 
  with the Act.â€Â  Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 344, 585 S.E.2d 
  281, 283 (2003) (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-40 (Supp. 2002)).Â Â Â Â  Section 
  15-78-60 of the South Carolina Code provides several exceptions to the waiver 
  of sovereign immunity.Â  â€œThese exceptions act as limitations on the liability 
  of a governmental entity.â€ Id. at 344, 585 S.E.2d at 283.Â  Among these 
  exceptions is one providing that a government entity is not liable for a loss 
  resulting from â€œnatural conditions of unimproved property of the governmental 
  entity, unless the defect or condition causing a loss is not corrected by the 
  particular governmental entity responsible for the property within a reasonable 
  time after actual or constructive notice of the defect or condition.â€Â  S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60 (10) (Supp. 2003).Â  
Therefore, the DOT cannot be liable for Saxonâ€™s 
  injuries unless the defect or condition that caused her injuries was not corrected 
  â€œwithin a reasonable time after actual or constructive notice of the defect 
  or condition.â€Â  See Richardson v. City of Columbia, 340 S.C. 515, 
  522, 532 S.E.2d 10, 14 (Ct. App. 2000) (finding City of Columbia not liable 
  for childâ€™s injuries sustained at baseball field â€œunless the defect or condition 
  that caused his injuries was â€˜not corrected by the particular governmental entity 
  responsible for maintenance, security, or supervision within a reasonable time 
  after actual notice of the defect or conditionâ€™â€ (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-60(16) 
  (Supp. 1999))).Â  The exceptions outlined within the Act must be liberally construed 
  in favor of limiting liability.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-20 (f) (Supp. 2003).Â  
  The burden of establishing an exception to the waiver of immunity under the 
  Tort Claims Act is upon the DOT.Â  Faile v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Juvenile 
  Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 540 (2002).Â  
The DOT sought to meet this burden by the testimony 
  of the highway patrolman.Â  The trooper testified that he traveled the road frequently, 
  it was his duty to report any problems, and he never saw any problems.Â  Furthermore, 
  a search of records showed no history of prior accidents at this intersection.Â  
  Based upon the stipulation that there was no record of prior accidents at this 
  intersection and the testimony of the trooper, the DOT established it did not 
  have actual notice of a dangerous condition. See Richardson, 340 
  S.C. at 525, 532 S.E.2d at 15 (holding City of Columbia did not have actual 
  notice of any condition or defect prior to childâ€™s accident at baseball field 
  where there were no prior complaints that the area was dangerous and no prior 
  injuries).Â  
Saxon, however, argues the DOT did have constructive 
  notice of overgrowth and reduced sight lines.Â  Specifically, Saxon asserts the 
  DOT was charged with constructive notice given it failed to anticipate and discover 
  the obstruction by making frequent and careful inspections. 
â€œConstructive notice is a legal inference which 
  substitutes for actual notice.Â  It is notice imputed to a person whose knowledge 
  of facts is sufficient to put him on inquiry; if these facts were pursued with 
  due diligence, they would lead to other undisclosed facts.â€ Strother v. Lexington 
  County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332 S.C. 54, 63 n.6, 504 S.E.2d 117, 122 
  n.6 (1998).Â  Constructive notice requires knowledge of facts sufficient 
  to have led the DOT to the danger.Â  The trooper, however, testified that he 
  was at the scene immediately after the accident and saw no problem with vegetation 
  overgrowth.Â  Despite this testimony, Saxon relies on Campbell v. South Carolina 
  State Highway Depâ€™t, 244 S.C. 186, 135 S.E.2d 838 (1964), overruled on 
  other grounds by McCall v. Batson, 285 S.C. 243, 329 S.E.2d 741 (1985) 
  (abolishing the doctrine of sovereign immunity); Inabinett v. South Carolina 
  State Highway Depâ€™t, 196 S.C. 117, 12 S.E.2d 848 (1941); and Ford v. 
  South Carolina Depâ€™t. of Transp., 328 S.C. 481, 492 S.E.2d 811 (Ct. App. 
  1997), for the proposition that the duty owed by the DOT to maintain safe roads 
  would require this court to find constructive notice and liability in this case.Â Â Â  

The DOT does in fact have a duty 
  to maintain safe roads and to discover and remedy potential hazards; however, 
  under the specific facts of this case, all testimony points to the existence 
  of adequate sight lines.Â  The DOT cannot be charged with constructive notice 
  that a dangerous condition existed when there is no testimony that any dangerous 
  condition actually existed.Â  Furthermore, each of the above-cited cases is distinguishable 
  from the instant case.Â  Unlike this case, there was evidence in each of the 
  cases regarding the dangerous condition prior to the incident that was the subject 
  of the lawsuit.Â  See Campbell, 244 S.C. at 190-91, 135 S.E.2d 
  at 840 (affirming denial of highway departmentâ€™s post-trial motions in case 
  involving motorcycle accident on negligently maintained mountain road where 
  highway department had on occasion repaired the road and was aware that the 
  drainage system was insufficient to take care of excess water); Inabinett, 
  196 S.C. at 123-24, 12 S.E.2d at 850 (affirming denial of highway departmentâ€™s 
  post-trial motions in case for personal injuries sustained when a tree alongside 
  a public highway fell onto plaintiffâ€™s vehicle where plaintiff offered testimony 
  that highway department was on constructive notice of the dangerous condition 
  given the decay of the tree was visible and the highway department had examined 
  the surrounding road shortly before the accident but had not discovered the 
  condition of the tree); Ford, 328 S.C. at 487-89, 492 S.E.2d at 814-15 
  (reversing grant of summary judgment in favor of highway department in case 
  arising from death of motorcyclist who collided with a fallen tree on the road 
  where department worked in the area intermittently in the weeks immediately 
  preceding the accident and an area neighbor informed the department prior to 
  the accident that trees were falling onto the road and were dangerous).
Because there was no actual notice of a dangerous condition, and it is impossible 
  to charge the DOT with constructive notice of a dangerous condition when there 
  is no testimony of a dangerous condition, we find the trial court properly directed 
  a verdict in favor of the DOT.Â  Thus, even assuming the DOTâ€™s improper maintenance 
  of the vegetation proximately caused Saxonâ€™s injuries, the DOT was immune from 
  liability under the Tort Claims Act given it did not have actual or constructive 
  notice of the defect or condition.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons stated above, 
  the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, CJ., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, AJ., concur.


 
   
    [1] Â  Saxon also filed suit against Thomas Cooler, the driver of the other 
    vehicle.Â  After discovery was completed, Saxon dismissed Cooler as a party. 
  

 
   [2] Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
    to Rule 215, SCACR.

 
   [3] Â  We note the DOT concedes in 
    its brief that Saxon presented â€œevidence of all of the elements of negligence 
    except proximate cause.â€

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        The Connecticut Indemnity Co., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Tyrone Davis and Francis Richard Burgess, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
  Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-436
  Submitted June 8, 2004 â€“ Filed July 26, 2004

REVERSED AND REMANDED

 
   
     
      
        Frank S. Potts, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        John W. Carrigg, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Connecticut Indemnity Company 
  (â€œConnecticutâ€) appeals the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of its declaratory judgment 
  action, arguing the court should have determined whether Connecticut was entitled 
  to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to the indemnity agreement.Â  We reverse 
  and remand. [1] 
FACTS
In 1992, Tyrone Davis suffered extensive damage to his home during a fire.Â  
  Davis hired contractor Francis Richard Burgess to repair the damage.Â  Burgess 
  was licensed by the Residential Builderâ€™s Commission (â€œthe Commissionâ€), and 
  Connecticut provided Burgess with a license bond. 
A dispute arose between Davis and Burgess concerning Burgessâ€™s performance.Â  
  Davis complained to the Commission, which issued an order on November 9, 1995, 
  directing Burgess to correct the omissions in his performance.Â  Davis contacted 
  Connecticut and requested the surety pay for the repairs.Â Â  
Connecticut wrote to Burgess requesting he respond 
  to Davisâ€™s allegations. Â Burgess informed Connecticut that he had settled 
  all issues with Davis, that he had been released, and that Davis was trying 
  to get something for nothing.Â  Burgess provided Connecticut with a copy of the 
  September 8, 1995 letter from the Commission stating the case had been officially 
  closed.Â  Connecticut sought clarification regarding the discrepancy between 
  the September 8, 1995 letter and the November 9, 1995 order from the Commission.Â  
  The Commission informed Connecticut that the previous â€œdismissalâ€ of the case 
  was only for the purpose of clearing its records and that the order in no way 
  relieved Burgess or Connecticut of their responsibilities to make corrections. 

Connecticut filed the underlying declaratory judgment 
  action requesting the trial court declare whether Davis was entitled to compensation 
  under the bond.Â  Connecticut asked the trial court to declare whether it was 
  â€œentitled to be fully and completely indemnified by the defendant Burgess, including 
  attorneyâ€™s fees, pursuant to the terms of the indemnity agreement between the 
  parties.â€Â  Davis counterclaimed for, among other things, bad faith refusal to 
  pay.Â Â  After repeated postponements, this case finally came up for trial on 
  September 16, 2002. 
At trial, Davis and Burgess settled their dispute for $6,500.Â  As part of the 
  settlement, both Davis and Burgess agreed to withdraw any claims they may have 
  had against Connecticut.Â  The trial court dismissed the case, finding the only 
  claim left was for a declaration of the terms of the indemnity agreement, and 
  for a declaration that the agreement required Burgess to pay Connecticutâ€™s attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and costs incurred in bringing the action. Â The court found the 
  remaining action to be a breach of contract action, concluded that it was inappropriate 
  to determine the contract issue in a declaratory judgment action, and dismissed 
  the case.Â  Connecticut filed a motion for reconsideration, which the court denied. 
  Â This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Declaratory judgment actions are neither legal nor equitable.Â  Wiedemann 
  v. Town of Hilton Head Island, 344 S.C. 233, 236, 542 S.E.2d 752, 753 (Ct. 
  App. 2001).Â  Therefore, the standard of review for a declaratory judgment action 
  is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.Â  Id.Â  The remaining 
  issue on appeal is a determination of attorneyâ€™s fees and costs pursuant to 
  the indemnity agreement.Â  Interpreting the terms of an agreement is an action 
  at law.Â  Barnacle Broad., Inc. v. Baker Broad., Inc., 343 S.C. 140, 146, 
  538 S.E.2d 672, 675 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding that interpretation of a contract 
  is an action at law); see also Weatherford v. Price, 340 S.C. 
  572, 578, 532 S.E.2d 310, 313 (Ct. App. 2000) (holding an action for attorneyâ€™s 
  fees, even one based on an implied agreement, is an action at law).Â  In an action 
  at law tried without a jury, the appellate court standard of review extends 
  only to the correction of errors of law.Â  Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 
  266 S.C. 81, 85, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976).Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s factual 
  findings will not be disturbed on appeal unless a review of the record discloses 
  that there is no evidence which reasonably supports the courtâ€™s findings.Â  Barnacle 
  Broad., Inc., 343 S.C. at 146, 538 S.E.2d at 675.
LAW/ANALYSIS 
Connecticut essentially argues the trial court erred in dismissing the case 
  because the court should have declared whether attorney's fees were due under 
  the indemnity agreement and, if so, established the amount due. We agree. 

    â€œUnder the Declaratory Judgment Act, a party 
      whose rights, status, or other legal relations are affected by a contract 
      may seek a courtâ€™s determination of any question of construction or validity 
      of the contract and obtain a declaration of the partyâ€™s rights, status, 
      or other legal relations thereunder.â€Â  Graham v. State Farm Mut. Auto. 
      Ins. Co., 319 S.C. 69, 71, 459 S.E.2d 844, 845 (1995); S.C. Code Ann. 
      Â§ 15-53-30 (1977); see also 22A Am. Jur. 2d Declaratory Judgments 
      Â§ 1 (2003) (â€œA declaratory judgment is an action in which the court declares 
      the rights, duties, status, or other legal relations between the parties.â€).Â  
      â€œThe Declaratory Judgment Act should be liberally construed to accomplish 
      its intended purpose of affording a speedy and inexpensive method of deciding 
      legal disputes and of settling legal rights and relationships, without awaiting 
      a violation of the rights or a disturbance of the relationships.â€Â  Graham, 
      319 S.C. at 71, 459 S.E.2d at 845; 22A Am. Jur. 2d Declaratory Judgments 
      Â§ 1 (2003) (holding that declaratory judgment actions â€œresolve uncertainties 
      and controversies before obligations are repudiated, rights are invaded 
      or wrongs are committed.â€).Â  
    
A party must demonstrate a justiciable controversy in order to state a claim 
  under the Declaratory Judgment Act.Â  Pond Place Partners, Inc. v. Poole, 
  351 S.C. 1, 16, 567 S.E.2d 881, 889 (Ct. App. 2002), cert. denied (June 
  12, 2003).Â  â€œA justiciable controversy exists when a concrete issue is present, 
  there is a definite assertion of legal rights and a positive legal duty which 
  is denied by the adverse party.â€Â  Graham, 319 S.C. at 71, 459 S.E.2d 
  at 845.Â Â  
At the time Connecticut brought the declaratory judgment action, a justiciable 
  controversy existed. It was not clear whether Burgess had been released, whether 
  Connecticut needed to pay Davis, or whether Burgess was required to reimburse 
  Connecticut or pay fees and costs under the indemnity agreement. When Burgess 
  and Davis settled at trial, the issue of determining if Burgess owed Davis became 
  moot. In addition, because Burgess and Davis agreed in the settlement to withdraw 
  any potential claims against Connecticut, the trial court no longer needed to 
  declare whether Burgess must indemnify Connecticut for any amount Connecticut 
  would have paid Davis. 
However, Connecticut's request that the trial court declare whether Burgess 
  owed Connecticut attorney's fees and costs pursuant to the indemnity agreement 
  was still before the trial court. We find the trial court committed an error 
  of law in finding the action was transformed into a breach of contract action, 
  prematurely dismissing the case, and failing to proceed further to determine 
  Connecticut's entitlement to attorney's fees and costs pursuant to the indemnity 
  agreement. Therefore, we reverse and remand this case to the trial court for 
  a determination of whether the indemnity agreement authorizes Connecticut to 
  receive attorney's fees and costs. If the trial court determines Connecticut 
  is entitled to fees, the trial court shall establish the amount of fees and 
  costs to be awarded.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
REVERSED AND REMANDED. 
  

HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur. 


   
     [1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant 
      to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED 
  ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
  
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Court of Appeals

 
   
     
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.
 
   
     
      
        Angela Almeida and Bright Ideas Child Development Center, Defendants,
        of whom Bright Ideas Child Development Center is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
  Â Richard W. Chewning, III, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2004-UP-437
  Heard June 9, 2004 â€“ Filed July 26, 2004

VACATED

 
   
     
      
        Jack B. Swerling, Robert â€œSamâ€ Phillips, and Harry L. Goldberg, all 
          of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Montford Shuler Caughman, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Bright Ideas Child Development 
  Center (â€œBright Ideasâ€) appeals a family court order permanently enjoining its 
  operation as a child daycare facility on the ground the injunction is unsupported 
  by any evidence.Â  We agree and vacate the order of the family court imposing 
  the permanent injunction.
FACTS
On January 28, 2003, Angela Almeida, the owner 
  and director of Bright Ideas, left the toddler room unattended to run errands.Â  
  At the same time, three of the five remaining caregivers left their individual 
  rooms unattended. [1] Â  A toddler was injured in Almeidaâ€™s absence. 
  [2] Â  Bright Ideas also had a history of repeated regulatory infractions, 
  many concerning staff training and supervision of children. 
On February 3, 2003, the Lexington County Department of Social Services initiated 
  an action to enjoin Bright Ideas and Angela Almeida from providing daycare services.Â  
  Prior to the scheduled hearing, however, DSS and Bright Ideas reached an accommodation 
  allowing the daycare to continue operating.Â  The parties agreed that if Angela 
  Almeida was enjoined from participating in any daycare activities, Bright Ideas 
  could continue to operate with a new owner and director.Â  Angela Almeidaâ€™s husband, 
  Tim, was named owner/operator and an existing employee became the director.Â  
  It was also agreed that Bright Ideas, DSS, and their attorneys would ensure 
  appropriate child-to-staff ratios and staffing compliance, including reductions 
  in child population as deemed necessary and that DSS would monitor the facility 
  every day.Â  By order dated February 4, 2003, the family court adopted the agreement.Â  
  The order also stated, the â€œ[r]uling on injunction shall be held in abeyance 
  pending strictest and fullest compliance with above agreement or this matter 
  will be brought back before the Court.â€ 
A dispute soon arose as to appropriate child-to-staff ratios, and Bright Ideas 
  declined to sign a corrective action plan requiring it to limit the number of 
  children under the age of two and reduce its overall child daycare population.Â  
  On February 11, 2003, DSS moved for a hearing on the original request for injunctive 
  relief because Bright Ideas failed to comply with the agreement respecting reductions 
  in child daycare population. 
After a hearing, the family court issued an order finding Bright Ideas posed 
  a substantial threat of harm to the public and children of Lexington County 
  in its â€œformer or present configuration.â€ As a result, the court permanently 
  enjoined Angela Almeida and Bright Ideas from providing daycare services. 
  [3] Â  Â Bright Ideas appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The decision to grant injunctive relief rests within 
  the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be overturned absent an 
  abuse of that discretion. City of Columbia v. Pic-A-Flick Video, Inc., 
  340 S.C. 278, 282, 531 S.E.2d 518, 520-21 (2000). â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs 
  when a trial courtâ€™s decision is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by 
  an error of law.â€ County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 
  560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).
DISCUSSION
Bright Ideas argues the family court erred in entering a permanent injunction 
  barring the daycare from future operations because there is no evidence to support 
  the injunction.Â  As the basis for this assertion, Bright Ideas claims it has 
  complied with the DSS requirements by severing all ties with Angela Almeida 
  and by operating without incident under its new management.Â  
In analyzing this issue, it is instructive to consider the underlying purpose 
  for injunctions.Â  The inherent purpose behind the equitable remedy of a temporary 
  injunction is to preserve the status quo.Â  Simpkins, 348 S.C. at 671, 
  560 S.E.2d at 905 (â€œâ€˜[A] temporary injunction is [used] to preserve the subject 
  of controversy in the condition which it is at the time of the Order until opportunity 
  is offered for full and deliberate investigation and to preserve the existing 
  status during litigation.â€™â€ (quoting County Council of Charleston v. Felkel, 
  244 S.C. 480, 483-84, 137 S.E.2d 577, 578 (1964))).Â  In contrast, â€œ[a] permanent 
  injunction is issued primarily to prevent future acts of harm and, unless specified 
  otherwise in the order, is unlimited in respect of time.â€Â  Bear v. Iowa Dist. 
  Court for Tama County, 540 N.W.2d 439, 441 (Iowa 1995);Â  see 42 Am. 
  Jur. 2d Injunctions Â§ 2 (2000) (â€œInjunctive relief is designed to meet 
  a real threat of a future wrong or a contemporary wrong of a nature likely to 
  continue or recur.Â  Whether interlocutory or final, injunctive relief is ordinarily 
  preventive or protective in character and restrains actions that have not yet 
  been taken.Â  It is generally not intended to redress, or punish for, past wrongs.â€).Â  
  Furthermore, â€œ[p]ermanent injunctions â€˜are permanent so long as the conditions 
  which produce the injunction remain permanent.â€™â€Â  Bear, 540 N.W.2d at 
  441 (quoting Condura Constr. Co. v. Milwaukee Bldg. & Constr. Trades 
  Council AFL, 99 N.W.2d 751, 755 (Wis. 1959)).Â Â  
This distinction is significant when compared with the terms of the statute 
  that was the basis for the injunction.Â  DSS is authorized by section 20-7-3010 
  to seek injunctive relief to prohibit the operation of a childcare facility 
  â€œ(1) when a facility is operating without a license or statement of registration; 
  (2) when there is any violation of this subarticle or of the regulations promulgated 
  by the department which threatens serious harm to children in the childcare 
  facility; (3) when an operator has repeatedly violated this subarticle or the 
  regulations of the department.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-3010 (Supp. 2003).Â  In 
  cases where, as here, the injunction sought is specifically authorized by statute 
  and the party seeking the injunction is a government entity, the government 
  entity must simply show (1) there is a statutory provision covering the situation; 
  and (2) that there is a violation of that provision. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 
  at 669, 560 S.E.2d at 905. â€œIn such circumstances, no showing of irreparable 
  harm need be made by the party seeking the injunction, nor must the court consider 
  whether the injunction is in the public interest.â€ Id. at 669, 560 S.E.2d 
  at 905 (quoting 42 Am. Jur. 2d Injunctions Â§ 23 (2000)).
 In order to obtain its requested injunction against Bright Ideas, DSS needed 
  to show evidence which would tend to establish any one of the three enumerated 
  grounds prescribed by section 20-7-3010.Â  As evidenced by the family courtâ€™s 
  order, DSS pursued the injunction under the second subsection, â€œwhen there is 
  any violation of this subarticle or of the regulations promulgated by the department 
  which threatens serious harm to children in the childcare facility.â€Â  
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-3010 (2) (Supp. 2003) (emphasis added).Â  By using the 
  term â€œthreatens,â€ we believe the General Assembly intended to abate future misconduct.Â  
  This interpretation is consistent with the purpose of a permanent injunction,
